As Whole Foods gets closer, Northtown Plaza empties out - The Buffalo News Local News Sections Home Local News Sports NCAA Basketball Bills Sabres Colleges High Schools High Schools Scoreboard Bandits Bisons and Baseball Bucky and Sully Soccer Outdoors WNY Auto Racing Bills Sabres Sabres 2016-17 season Gusto Food and Drink Music Festivals Theater Family Movies Comedy Art Dance Deaths Death Notices Obituaries Submit Obituary Last 24 Hours E-edition Business Crime Editorials Education Events Calendar Submit Event Photo Galleries Politics PolitiFact New York TV and Media Weather Forecast Weddings Submit Announcement Submit Golden Anniversary WNY History [BN] Ads Buffalo Job Finder Buffalo Cars Special Sections Buffalo Magazine Buffalo Brides Buffalo Home Finder Classifieds Contests Communities Erie County Amherst Buffalo Hamburg Lancaster Town of Tonawanda Niagara County Health and Fitness Lifestyles Books Fashion Gardening Home and Style NeXt Opinion Editorials Letters to the Editor Adam Zyglis State Search Sign In Subscribe Manage Account Logout As Whole Foods gets closer, Northtown Plaza empties out Only six stores remain open at Northtown Plaza, despite it being located hear one of the busiest intersections in Amherst. (Robert Kirkham/Buffalo News) By Stephen T. Watson Published Tue, May 16, 2017 SHARE TWEET EMAIL WS Development has a picture on its website of a bustling shopping plaza in Amherst with two rows of shops lining a packed parking lot. The Massachusetts-based developer calls it a "highly visible retail destination" that hosts the region's only Whole Foods. The reality at the former Northtown Plaza is far different. Although Whole Foods is under construction and is scheduled to open this summer, most of Northtown's storefronts sit empty. Six tenants remain, including a hair salon and a butcher shop. "The plaza definitely needs to have some life breathed back into it," said Michael Baer, who, with his wife, owns the Northtown Plaza Fantastic Sams and three other salons in the area. As shopping centers across the country struggle and online retailing grows, shoppers wonder what will happen to one of the region's oldest and most visible retail centers. WS Development, a major national owner of shopping centers, bought the Northtown Plaza two years ago and initially talked about spending as much as $75 million to transform it. [Gallery: What's the future of Northtown Plaza?] The developer has nudged out tenants that don't fit with its vision – not an unusual step when an owner attracts a new anchor store and rebuilds a center. Observers expect the company will tear down existing stores to make way for new tenants. But so far the company isn't saying much about what it intends to do. The developer declined an interview request. "We continue to refine plans for the future phases of redevelopment and look forward to sharing details in the future," Sherri D'Alessandro, a WS Development spokeswoman, said in an email. The lack of action makes locals nervous. "I wish I understood. I wish they would talk to somebody," said Natalie Neumann, owner of Riverside Men's Shop, which moved this month from the plaza to a new store in Depew. Natalie Neuman, left, owner of Riverside Mens Shop, discusses their on-going move from Northtown Plaza with her store manager Joe Jacobi at their Northtown Plaza location on Wednesday, April 19, 2017 in Amherst, N.Y. (Robert Kirkham/Buffalo News)Plaza sold for $18.5 million When WS Development came to Amherst, the two rows of stores and retail space that make up the Northtown Plaza largely were filled. But over the last two years, restaurants, service outlets and mom-and-pop retail shops have moved or closed. The Erie County Auto Bureau left for a plaza in the Town of Tonawanda. The Screening Room movie theater decamped to the Boulevard Mall. My Tomato Pie opened a new restaurant in north Amherst. C-K Nail and Spa was the latest to clear out, reopening around the corner at 1060 Niagara Falls Blvd., in the last couple of weeks. Six businesses remain: Treats Unleashed pet store, Federal Meats, KeyBank, Payless ShoeSource, Fantastic Sams and the women's clothing store Mabel Danahy. Located near the heavily trafficked corner of Sheridan Drive and Niagara Falls Boulevard, the plaza was built on farmland 65 years ago. WS Development paid $18.5 million in 2015 for the 19-acre plaza, which has 375,000 square feet of space, or twice the size of the Walmart Supercenter on Sheridan Drive. WS Development has a track record of success. The company, for example, paid $45 million in 2013 for Hyde Park Village, a six-block commercial development in Tampa, Fla., and has brought in a trendy mix of national and local retailers, such as preppy clothing store Vineyard Vines, according to the online magazine 83 Degrees. But at Northtown, the only sign of progress in the plaza is the construction on the $15 million Whole Foods, where work began last summer. WS Development at one time approached the Amherst Industrial Development Agency about obtaining tax breaks to subsidize the cost of the development. Under agency policy, retail stores don't qualify for tax breaks but "tourist destinations" do. David S. Mingoia, the agency's executive director, said IDA officials tried to steer the developer toward converting the plaza to a mixed-use development. The developer has offered to buy out Baer, who has a lease that runs through 2023. He said he is in negotiations to exit the Northtown Plaza and move to a building near the plaza. Federal Meats, an original tenant in the plaza, has a month-to-month lease but hasn't had much communication with WS Development. It's not easy to move a butcher shop, because of all of the coolers and the display cases, said Patrick Patterson, the store manager. But he said he knows that day is coming as Whole Foods gets closer to opening. "That's the last thing they want is any competition," said Patterson. As other tenants left the plaza over the past two years, business became "extremely challenging" for Riverside Men's Shop, said Neumann. "The bright side? Plenty of parking," quipped Tom Lanighan, the store's sales manager. The Whole Foods store under construction at Northtown Plaza on Wednesday, April 19, 2017. (Robert Kirkham/Buffalo News) Whole Foods plans Plans filed with the town for Whole Foods show typical features, such as a bakery and extensive space for prepared foods. But the Amherst Whole Foods also would boast a casual restaurant serving food and beer, a bocce ball court and a "living wall" of plants on the roof. Amherst Whole Foods to feature bocce court, tap room Whole Foods and WS have said the store will be ready to open this summer. Representatives of both companies declined last week to provide an update on the construction. Nationally, the organic grocery chain is mired in a prolonged sales slump and is under pressure to draw in new shoppers and shake off its reputation for high prices. Whole Foods used to dominate the natural and organic food marketplace, but Kroger and even Walmart have jumped into that space nationally, said Chuck Lindsey, an associate professor in the University at Buffalo marketing department. "They're not the only game in town anymore," he said. The company has scaled back expansion plans across the country, Lindsey said, but so far has not said the Amherst store is affected. "Things are still on track," Ted Kwong, a Whole Foods spokesman, said in an email. Competition nearby The clearing out of the Northtown Plaza comes at a time of growth – and uncertainty – for major retail centers along the Niagara Falls Boulevard-Sheridan Drive axis. Boulevard Consumer Square, the shopping plaza 1½ miles north of the Northtown Plaza, recently added Nordstrom Rack. The Boulevard Mall still has its Macy's and JCPenney anchors but lost Sears earlier this year. Six years ago, BJ's Wholesale Club moved into a long-vacant storefront in the 23-acre TJ Maxx plaza at Sheridan and Niagara Falls Boulevard.  And a Walmart moved into the former Hills-Ames plaza at Sheridan and North Bailey Avenue. "You look down that street, it's a big improvement from what it was 10 years ago," said David Schiller, associate broker with Pyramid Brokerage Co., which has listed the former Boulevard Mall Sears. A smaller-scale example of a retail revival on Sheridan is Benderson Development's Piccadilly Plaza, at North Bailey. That's where the Taste of India restaurant moved after leaving Northtown Plaza. Benderson bought the plaza in late 2015 and started fixing up the exteriors of the storefronts and making other renovations late last year, said Eric Recoon, a vice president of development and leasing. Benderson built new standalone buildings for Starbucks, Sleep Number and Dickey's BBQ. "We felt very strongly about the underlying real estate – fantastic location – but a meaningful investment was needed to bring it to a standard we feel comfortable with, as well as to attract new national tenants," Recoon said. Back at Northtown, as Patterson offered made-from-scratch chicken noodle soup to a visitor to Federal Meats, he said he looks forward to seeing something happen. "If they do what they say they're gonna do," he said, "it'll be quite a destination." --- Stores that closed or moved from Northtown Plaza after WS Development bought it in 2015 Gi-Ro Cleaners Cutting Edge Sports Training Shoppers' Choice Close-Out Bargain Stores My Burger Bar Riverside Men's Shop S+E Jewelers Falafel Bar My Tomato Pie Taste of India Erie County Auto Bureau Plato's Closet Clothes Mentor Goldmaster Studios Carolina Furniture Screening Room C-K Nails + Spa Click here to see the comments. Add yours now! Search the print archives This copy is for your personal non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies of Toronto Star content for distribution to colleagues, clients or customers, or inquire about permissions/licensing, please go to: www.TorontoStarReprints.com Business Canadian traditional grocers see slowing market share loss to Costco, Walmart “The traditional grocers have done a better job defending share than, I think, a lot of observers expected,” says a consumer and retail analyst. Industry watchers say the price gap between Canadian grocers and international retailers Costco and Walmart has narrowed and the traditional stores’ loyalty programs are helping support sales.  (Nathan Denette / THE CANADIAN PRESS)   By Aleksandra SaganThe Canadian Press Tues., May 16, 2017 While international retailers Costco and Walmart have gobbled up a growing share of Canadian food sales for more than a decade, further gains are expected to be tougher to eke out as the country’s traditional grocers mount an improved defence. Industry watchers say the price gap between the two sides has narrowed and the traditional stores’ loyalty programs are helping support sales. “Every point of market share is hard fought over in the grocery market,” said Kenric Tyghe, a consumer and retail analyst at Raymond James. “The traditional grocers have done a better job defending share than, I think, a lot of observers expected.” While they have operated in Canada for years, competition from Costco and Walmart is still top of mind for local grocers given the low-cost strategy of the two foreign giants. In his most recent quarterly call with analysts in April, Metro CEO Eric La Fleche discussed Costco’s expansion in Ontario, saying it is “a significant competitor, and we have to execute and differentiate.” Article Continued Below In the second quarter of 2004, traditional grocery stores sold about $12.3 billion worth of food, accounting for about 90 per cent of the market, according to Statistics Canada data. General merchandisers, which include Costco and Walmart, sold about $1.3 billion or roughly 9.8 per cent. In the same quarter of 2016, traditional grocers’ market share fell to about 79.2 per cent, while that of the general merchandisers more than doubled. Those changes translate “into billions and billions of dollars every quarter,” said Kevin Grier, an agriculture and food market analyst, adding that the shift in market share to the U.S. chains is expected to slow. “You can’t keep that up,” he said. Canadian grocers were granted some respite from foreign-owned competitors when Target, which entered the Canadian market in 2013, pulled out of the country in 2015. Costco now operates 95 warehouses in Canada, while Walmart runs 410 stores. Costco plans to open three more stores by the end of this year for a total of seven new stores in 2017. Spokesperson Ron Damiani said that’s the most sites the company’s opened in a financial year in recent memory. While Walmart has not revealed any new expansion plans, it announced in 2015 it would add 42 supercentre locations. Tyghe said that pace of expansion will not create the sort of disruption and dislocation seen when growth in square footage at the two chains outpaced population increases, forcing Canadian grocers to lower prices. The traditional grocers have also boosted their discount banner store counts, Tyghe said, keeping their hold on the most price-oriented customers. Loblaw, for example, operates 500 discount banner stores, including No Frills, across Canada. “We believe we have some of the strongest, most effectively operated and most customer-centric discount formats in the country,” Loblaw CEO Galen Weston said in an interview after the company’s annual meeting earlier this month. For the average Canadian shopper, that means the price difference between a product at a traditional grocer and a Costco or Walmart is not necessarily compelling enough to justify shopping at two separate locations, Tyghe said. “You’re not going to win on price alone,” he said. Another factor favouring traditional grocers is their strong loyalty programs, which give them robust customer data and the ability to target promotional offers to individuals based on their shopping habits, Tyghe said. “How they respond is increasingly in a very data-driven, targeted, promotional way,” he said. Read more about: Walmart, Costco Delivered dailyThe Morning Headlines Newsletter Subscribe The Toronto Star and thestar.com, each property of Toronto Star Newspapers Limited, One Yonge Street, 4th Floor, Toronto, ON, M5E 1E6. Walmart investigates note found recounting forced labor in China; includes company's statement Author: Sébastien Malo, Thomson Reuters Foundations, Published on: 16 May 2017 Giant U.S. retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc said on Wednesday it is looking into the origins of a note describing forced labor conditions in China that a customer claimed to find in a purse bought at a store in Arizona. The note detailed long hours, beatings and malnourishment of workers at a prison in the Chinese region of Guangxi, according to the customer's family who contacted local media... "We're making contact with the customer and appreciate her bringing this to our attention. With the information we have, we are looking into what happened so we can take the appropriate actions," Ragan Dickens, a Wal-Mart spokesman, said...The customer told local media late last month that the note was hand-written in Chinese but she had it translated into English three times... In a similar case, in 2014 a woman found a message in a Saks Fifth Avenue shopping bag from a man saying he was forced to work long hours at a Chinese prison factory. The worker was tracked down, and the note deemed legitimate. He was later released... "Following" : "Follow"}} May 16, 2017 7:54am   Comments Share: Related WMT Fast Money Traders Share Their Picks In Retail Sector Retail Earnings Roll On With Wal-Mart And Target On Calendar; Housing Data Too Cypress Wealth Advisors LLC Buys Vanguard Information Tech ETF - DNQ, Sunoco Logistics Partners ... (GuruFocus) Related AMZN Jim Cramer's Retail Picks Ahead Of A Busy Earnings Week The Difference A Year Makes: Analyst Who Upgraded JC Penney A Year Ago 'Recalibrates' Expectations Kayak Investment Partners LLC Buys Himax Technologies Inc, Microsoft Corp, Zillow Group Inc, ... (GuruFocus) Traditional retailers are gearing up to take on the rivalry posed by online behemoth Amazon.com, Inc. (NASDAQ: AMZN). As a step in the right direction, Wal-Mart Stores Inc (NYSE: WMT) announced in a blog last week it's testing new approaches in two recently owned supercenters in Tomball, Texas, and Lake Nona, Florida. This is in a bid to appeal to customers, who are increasingly taking to digital-driven lifestyles. Scan & Go: Valuing Customers' Time Realizing customer time constraints, Wal-Mart has begun testing Scan & Go technology, which works both on personal smartphones and Wal-Mart provided handheld devices. The Scan & Go wands and digital produce scales are available on the way into the store. A customer can pick up a scanner from a rack near the door and go about the store, picking up items he wants to purchase. The customer scans the items and then puts them into the shopping bags. At the checkout, the customer needs to point the scanner at the kiosk, pay using the card and he will be done. "The Scan & Go fast pass checkout lanes allow customers to bypass the traditional checkout process, which makes a quick trip faster than ever," Wal-Mart said. The 5–7 minutes it takes to checkout with a cashier now shrinks to 32 seconds, an ABC report said. How Does Scan & Go Compare To Amazon Go Stores? Amazon began testing Amazon Go stores late last year in Seattle for groceries purchases in brick-and-mortar stores. The small-store concept was supposed to serve as small convenience stores rather than as a bigger grocery store. Though Amazon said the store concept would go live in early 2017, the rollout appears to be courting a delay. The Go store concept works like this: Customers are provided with access to the stores after they wipe their Amazon Go App. Customers can go around shopping and scan the items they plan to buy using their smartphones and then walk out without having to wait in checkout queues. The items they place back after picking up will be deducted from their shopping cart. The bill or receipt will be sent via email. A Forbes article, quoting a report, suggests that the buying process in the Go stores breaks down if more than 20 people shop in the marketplace at a time. Once more customers enter the store or when they slow their movements, Amazon's technology can't easily track them and the purchasing process breaks down, the report said. Apart from Scan & Go, Wal-Mart is also testing other boosted convenience approaches, such as: New Layout: The company reimagined the layout based on customer shopping behavior. Services such as beauty salon and tech repairs were placed adjacent to relevant merchandise. Smart Life: New interactive projection technology allows customers to learn about connected devices such as Alphabet Inc (NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)'s Google Home, Apple Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL)'s TV, Nest, baby monitors and connected thermostats. Integrated Pickup: Shoppers can use the outside drive-thru to pick up not just their weekly groceries, but also their prescriptions and Walmart.com orders. Extended Aisles: Interactive screens offer access to an extended curated selection of online-only items in almost 100 categories. Customers can order products, pay with the rest of their basket at checkout and pick up two days later. Appointment Setting: This allows placement of orders, an interlude of time, and then the order pick up. Related Links: Should Wal-Mart Investors Be Concerned That Amazon Invited Food Execs To Its Seattle Office? How Wal-Mart Can Beat Amazon: Copy What Amazon Does Best _______ Image Credit: By SounderBruce (Own work) [CC BY-SA 4.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons Posted-In: ABC Amazon Go cashierless store Scan & GoNews Retail Sales Tech Trading Ideas Best of Benzinga © 2017 Benzinga.com. Tech Apple Science Cars Samsung Nintendo Switch iPhone 7S & 8 Nintendo NES E3     Nintendo Switch Stock Updates For Tuesday, May 16 Posted: May 16 2017, 4:18am CDT | by Luigi Lugmayr, in News | Technology News     The latest Nintendo Switch stock tracking information for online and in stores for Tuesday, May 16th. The Nintendo Switch console is available online only as part of bundles. GameStop has replaced the three Switch bundles the video game retailer offered last week on the weekend with three completely new Nintendo Switch bundles. Target is now also offering a Nintendo Switch bundle online at target.com. Don't Miss: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy-Con in Stock Online The GameStop Nintendo Switch bundles are the only option to buy a Nintendo Switch online on Monday.  Shoppers can track the availability of the four Nintendo Switch bundles with our new app The Tracker. Check the availability of the Nintendo Switch Neon Joy-Con Digital Bundle, Nintendo Switch Gray Joy-Con Bundle, Nintendo Switch Neon Joy-Con Physical Bundle and the new Nintendo Switch Gray Joy-Con Starter Bundle. This week the Nintendo Dock Set will ship and also new Nintendo Switch games will be released. Every new Switch game release is still a highlight as the catalog of available Switch games is still very limited.  Nintendo believes the Nintendo Switch will be as big as the extremely successful Nintendo Wii. Looking at the current shortage, the Japanese video game maker has a long road ahead of them to ship 101 million Nintendo Switch consoles. The positive reception and praise of the Nintendo Switch fuel the demand for the mobile and home console hybrid. Nintendo is also busy marketing the Nintendo Switch with hands-on events and at the E3 2017. Find below the latest Nintendo Switch online availability updates and stock tracking updates for stores. Nintendo Switch Stock at Online Stores On Monday the Nintendo Switch is available online as part of three new bundles starting at $484.99 online at gamestop.com.  Target's Nintendo Switch bundle on offer at target.com sells for $499.99. It is rather attractive bundle including Pro Controller, Zelda, Mario Kart and a bag. The Switch bundle at Target ships now, while the three GameStop offers ship May 26. The Nintendo Switch has been on sale on Friday, May 11 again at 5pm ET. Walmart's Nintendo Switch flash sale was over in minutes.  The Switch was available as a custom bundle. Through the Walmart app the $299 Switch consoles have been available too. To get an notification when Walmart is again selling the Nintendo Switch online try our new Tracker app. The Switch is extremely hard to score on Friday a walmart.com. A lot of successful orders got cancelled afterwards as Walmart sold more than they had available. It is a headscratcher why Walmart's shopping platform is not able to keep sales and stock in sync. Amazon in the UK is offering the Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy-Con with an in stock date of May 25. The price of the UK import comes to $332.22 with 5 day shipping.  At this point no online retailer is selling the $299.99 Nintendo Switch consoles. The Nintendo Switch will continue to be hard to find for the foreseeable future. Nintendo plans to ship 10 million consoles world-wide in the time from April 2017 to April 2018. From the launch on Mach 3 to April 27, the Mario company sold 2.74 million Switch consoles. Online stores restocked the $299.99 Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy-Con and the $299.99 Nintendo Switch with Neon Joy-Con in time for the launch of Mario Kart 8 Deluxe on April 28. Since then the Switch console was out of stock online, besides the TRU bundle offer, according to data from The Tracker. The Nintendo Switch reseller markups keep steady and range today between $90 to $110 for the Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy-Con and $100 to $130 for the Nintendo Switch with Neon Joy-Con on amazon.com. The Nintendo Switch with Neon Joy-Con is more rare than the console with Gray controllers, resulting in considerable higher market value. Overall the Nintendo Switch market prices have risen slightly. To find Nintendo Switch in stock online, shoppers can use our new The Tracker app, available as free download for iOS and Android.  There are also several new accessories coming on the market from Nintendo in the next weeks. See the full list of new Nintendo Switch accessories. When is Nintendo Switch in stock online again? Nintendo is ramping up the production for the Nintendo Switch, but has not disclosed what the current production capacity per month is. The demand for the Nintendo Switch will spike during the Holiday Shopping season 2017. Nintendo will set aside a large part of the Switch production during the next months for November and December. This stock piling will keep the Nintendo Switch in short supply during the next 5 months. As Nintendo coordinated new Switch console shipment with the launch of Mario Kart 8, we expect the company to do the same for the next major Switch game launches. This means the next big wave of new Switch consoles comes in mid-June for the release of ARMS. The Nintendo Switch will likely be offered in special bundles in time for the Holidays. A Mario Kart 8 Deluxe Switch bundle has already surfaced in Russia. Because of the incredible demand for the Switch console, the monetary savings on these bundles will be limited. Usually bundles offer a way for consumers to get a free game. Nintendo can afford to just offer some savings, unless the demand is slowing down. Read the latest Nintendo Switch news. How to find a Nintendo Switch in Stock Online We developed the The Tracker app to make finding stock of rare products online as easy and stress free as possible. Download the free app for Apple iPhone or Android phones. From the list products you select to be notified for the Switch with Grey Joy-Con and/or Neon Joy-Con. That is it. It is set and forget. At the moment we detect the Nintendo Switch console in stock at major online retailers, you receive a notification on your smartphone. Now you are just a tap away from buying a Nintendo Switch. You can also see the current availability of the Nintendo Switch consoles in the web version of The Tracker: Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy-Con, Nintendo Switch with Neon Joy-Con. Nintendo Switch in Stock at Stores GameStop is restocking the Nintendo Switch since Thursday in stores too. The Nintendo Switch is also only available as part of bundles at GameStop retail locations. The Nintendo Switch is available in 585 Walmart stores, 185 Target stores, 19 GameStop locations according to the Nintendo Switch inventory tracker iStockNow (5:15am ET). The number of stores stayed basically the same compared to Monday, which is not a good sign. It is still early and new inventory could still arrive at stores later this morning. The Nintendo flagship store in New York said on April 28 in a tweet to have the Nintendo Switch in stock each morning. People in New York or visitors can give this purchase option a try. Social media posts from people who visited the flagship store confirm the availability of the Switch at the Nintendo store in New York. Some even report that they saw the Switch still on the shelves late afternoon. Read the latest Nintendo Switch news. Updated: 2017-05-17 01:55:42am Offers Nintendo Switch Neon Joy-Con Digital Bundle Store: Gamestop Price: $499.99 Availability: Browse all current Offers This story may contain affiliate links. Little girl dressed as Frozen princess is used by her own mother to steal another family's $1,800 Bugaboo stroller at Disney World Put Vaseline up your nose, gargle with mouthwash and NEVER drink alcohol: The secrets to staying healthy on board a long haul flight Previous Next Actor gets EPIC revenge on baffled tax scammers asking for $5,680 by giving out fake details, pretending to go to Walmart to pay them - and then asking them out to lunch 902010 star Ashton Bingham, of LA, was ordered to pay $5,680 in unpaid tax  Bingham asked if he could bring his dog to Walmart while he took out the cash  He also pretended to feel suicidal, so scammer said to him: 'I love you. Stay on'  At end of call he branded scammer an 'inebriated dog s***' who will 'burn in hell' By Ekin Karasin For Mailonline Published: 06:10 EDT, 16 May 2017 | Updated: 13:34 EDT, 16 May 2017 e-mail 116 shares 39 View comments An actor got epic revenge on an IRS scam-caller by pretending to go to a Walmart to pay him, giving fake card details and even asking the scammer to go to lunch. 902010 star Ashton Bingham, of Studio City, Los Angeles, was ordered to pay $5,680 in unpaid tax - and decided to go along with it. A clip shows the actor pretending that he feels suicidal halfway through the call, which prompts the scammer to say: 'I love you. Stay on.' Mr Bingham finally unleashes hell in a scathing rant at the end of the video, telling the scammer he is an 'inebriated dog s***' who will 'burn in hell'. Actor Ashton Bingham got epic revenge on an IRS scam-caller by pretending to go to a Walmart, giving false card details and even asking the scammer to go to lunch with him 902010 star Ashton Bingham, of Studio City, Los Angeles, was ordered to pay $5,680 in unpaid tax - and decided to go along with it The video begins with Mr Bingham, from northern Nevada, holding out his mobile, which is on speakerphone. 'We have called to inform you about a lawsuit filed in your name, sir. Do you file your taxes by own or do you have anyone else filing your taxes?' the scammer asks. 'Oh, I've never been to Texas?' He replies sardonically. 'I will go ahead and read all the charges against your name, but before I do that do not interrupt me as I will give you a fair time to speak, alright?  RELATED ARTICLES Previous 1 Next Shocking moment cruel nanny SLAPS a toddler in the face is... Massive surge in online scams as victims are conned out of... 'Idiotic' husband, 23, uses a hot coathanger to brand a... Chilling phone call of chef as he cooked his dismembered... Share this article Share 116 shares Grinning with mischief, the Parks And Recreation star interrupts to say: 'Okay.' The scammer claims that the actor needs to pay around $4,800 in unpaid tax and threatens that the IRS has issued an arrest warrant.  'Oh noooo,' Mr Bingham replies in mock-horror.   The scammer then transfers him to a 'senior investigating officer'. The next man seems to be feeling optimistic about his chances, and bumps up the amount of unpaid tax to $5,680. 'I'm a little strapped on funds at the moment because I have a lot of medical bills and I went to the doctor six months ago and I was diagnosed with Plumber's crack,' Mr Bingham claims. The scammer threatens that the IRS has issued an arrest warrant for Mr Bingham, to which he replies in mock-horror 'Oh nooooo' A clip shows the actor pretending that he feels suicidal and wants to kill himself halfway through the call, prompting the scammer to urge: 'I love you. Stay like this forever' The scammer persists: 'Do you have the $5,680 or not?' 'Yeah I do, I was gonna go to Knott's Berry Farm [theme park in California] but I guess I can just cancel that. So yeah I have it,' Mr Bingham trails off sadly.  He is then transferred to a third 'senior investigating officer', who demands that Mr Bingham transfer the money 'by himself'. 'By myself? Can I bring my dog?' he asks. 'Why would you want to bring your dog?' the scammer shoots back furiously, to which he replies: 'Well, I'm just a little scared and he's a service animal.' 'Sir, this is a recorded line, what are you talking about sir?' the scammer blusters. The scammer then orders him to go to a Walmart store to drop off the money. Mr Bingham blags: 'Yeah, I'm almost there. I'm walking up to the parking lot. This really sucks you know, all these horrible things happening. 'I don't know man, I'm just - I'm just starting to lose my will to be alive, you know. Like sometimes I feel like I need to like, end it, you know?' There is a pause on the end of the line, before the scammer tentatively responds: 'You're just a smart guy, man.' Mr Bingham then pretends to go to a Walmart, at which point the scammer seems to realise he is being played and tries desperately to get the actor to take out $500  Getting increasingly desperate, he adds: 'I love you. I love the way you are. Stay like this forever okay? Stay on.' Mr Bingham then asks in a quivering voice: 'Really? You don't think I should kill myself?' When the scammer replies that he shouldn't, the actor ventures: 'Oh. Can we hang out after I get this settled? Do you like lunch? Do you eat lunch?' 'I don't know,' the baffled scammer replies, to which Mr Bingham says dejectedly, 'Oh, you don't eat lunch.' When the actor claims he is in Walmart, the scammer finally seems to catch on and starts laughing bitterly. 'You're a smart guy, man. Do you have money or not? Get a card of $500,' he says. He then changes his mind, saying: 'Why don't you get me $100 then.' Mr Bingham wastes even more time by asking if he should also buy a Walmart gift card.  The scammer seems on the verge of hanging up, when the actor says: 'OK, I'm ready, I have the card.' As he reads out the fake numbers, the scammer yells: 'Sir, do you think I am a fool?' 'No, I think you're a c*** sucking, lint-licking piece of inebriated c*** sucking dog s***. That's what I think,' Mr Bingham finally vents. As he reads out the fake numbers, the scammer yells: 'Sir, do you think I am a fool?' 'No, I think you're a c*** sucking, lint-licking piece of inebriated c*** sucking dog s***. That's what I think,' Mr Bingham finally vents 'You're gonna burn in hell, because you're a stupid motherf****** scamming motherf***.' The other end of the line then bursts into static as the scammers start furiously shouting in a different language. 'Hello? F***face?' asks Mr Bingham, before shrugging and hanging up. Amused viewers praised the video in their droves, with one writing: 'You are a great man sir!  'Wasting the scammers' time so they will not scam other people. You maybe just save 3-5 people from being scammed. May God bless you.' Another added: 'Diagnosed with plumber crack. DEAD!' The actor, who was previously a magician, explains on his Twitter bio: 'I make movies and mess with scammers for a living. Life is awesome. #blessed.' Last year he made a similar pranking video of an IRS caller who he kept on the phone for 40 minutes before shouting: 'Stop f***ing scamming people, you stupid dumb son of a b****'.   Share or comment on this article e-mail 116 shares Most watched News videos Phoney business: Hilarious man plays telephone scammers Moment cyclist gets shot by stray bullet during group ride Angry woman goes on racist tirade against couple fishing in her area Golfers watch on as huge alligator chows down on fish Miss District of Columbia crowned Miss USA 2017 Police in Baltimore discover toddler in car of man shot dead Heartwarming mother-daughter pit bull reunion at ASPCA Gronk celebrates his birthday with hot date at friend's wedding Moment owner breaks up fight between two young Rottweilers Bridesmaid seeks legal action after filmed 'attack' at wedding Gangster dog: Kid looks shocked as dog drives past him McMaster denies Trump revealed classified info to Russians Shocking moment cyclist is hit by stray bullet from... Politics Smart Living Money Entertainment Health Tech Science Sports Video Contests Live Like Follow Canada May 16, 2017 5:36 am Updated: May 16, 2017 3:01 pm Costco, Walmart losing some ground to traditional grocers in Canadian food sales By Aleksandra Sagan The Canadian Press ; Loblaw-owned No Frills as well as Metro banner Food Basics are ramping up discounts to counter deals at Walmart and Costco. Getty Images What is this? Sponsored content is written by Global News' editorial staff without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... What is this ? X What is this? Sponsored content is written by Global News' without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... - A A + Listen TORONTO – While international retailers Costco and Walmart have gobbled up a growing share of Canadian food sales for more than a decade, further gains are expected to be tougher to eke out as the country’s traditional grocers mount an improved defence. Industry watchers say the price gap between the two sides has narrowed and the traditional stores’ loyalty programs are helping support sales. “Every point of market share is hard fought over in the grocery market,” said Kenric S. Tyghe, a consumer and retail analyst at Raymond James. “The traditional grocers have done a better job defending share than, I think, a lot of observers expected.” 00:48 Consumer Costco continues to muscle in on Canadian supermarkets 00:27 Consumer Facebook video questions Calgary Walmart’s treatment of customers 02:25 BC1 Costco grabbing bigger share of grocery market Story continues below While they have operated in Canada for years, competition from Costco and Walmart is still top of mind for local grocers given the low-cost strategy of the two foreign giants. In his most recent quarterly call with analysts in April, Metro CEO Eric R. La Fleche discussed Costco’s expansion in Ontario, saying it is “a significant competitor, and we have to execute and differentiate.” In the second quarter of 2004, traditional grocery stores sold about $12.3 billion worth of food, accounting for about 90 per cent of the market, according to Statistics Canada data. General merchandisers, which include Costco and Walmart, sold about $1.3 billion or roughly 9.8 per cent. READ MORE: Walmart Canada makes jump to being a ‘real grocer’ In the same quarter of 2016, traditional grocers’ market share fell to about 79.2 per cent, while that of the general merchandisers more than doubled. Those changes translate “into billions and billions of dollars every quarter,” said Kevin Grier, an agriculture and food market analyst, adding that the shift in market share to the U.S. chains is expected to slow. “You can’t keep that up,” he said. Canadian grocers were granted some respite from foreign-owned competitors when Target, which entered the Canadian market in 2013, pulled out of the country in 2015. Costco now operates 95 warehouses in Canada, while Walmart runs 410 stores. Costco plans to open three more stores by the end of this year for a total of seven new stores in 2017. Spokesman Ron Damiani said that’s the most sites the company’s opened in a financial year in recent memory. READ MORE: Canadian grocers’ move to cage-free eggs an ‘important commitment’ While Walmart has not revealed any new expansion plans, it announced in 2015 it would add 42 supercentre locations. Tyghe said that pace of expansion will not create the sort of disruption and dislocation seen when growth in square footage at the two chains outpaced population increases, forcing Canadian grocers to lower prices. The traditional grocers have also boosted their discount banner store counts, Tyghe said, keeping their hold on the most price-oriented customers. Loblaw, for example, operates 500 discount banner stores, including No Frills, across Canada. “We believe we have some of the strongest, most effectively operated and most customer-centric discount formats in the country,” Loblaw CEO Galen G. Weston said in an interview after the company’s annual meeting earlier this month. READ MORE: Okanagan grocer nationally recognized for helping new Canadians For the average Canadian shopper, that means the price difference between a product at a traditional grocer and a Costco or Walmart is not necessarily compelling enough to justify shopping at two separate locations, Tyghe said. “You’re not going to win on price alone,” he said. Another factor favouring traditional grocers is their strong loyalty programs, which give them robust customer data and the ability to target promotional offers to individuals based on their shopping habits, Tyghe said. “How they respond is increasingly in a very data-driven, targeted, promotional way,” he said. – With files from Linda Nguyen Report an error Canadian grocers Costco Discount discount banners Loblaws Loyalty programs metro No Frills supermarket traditional grocers Walmart Editor's Picks 25th amendment There's a process to remove incapable presidents, but it probably won't be used on Trump — yet Fake News Beware reports based on screenshotted tweets — here's why (again) Canada Moody's downgrades Canadian banks: Beginning of the end for the housing market? Shopping Jobs Driving Homes Remembering Celebrating Newspapers TV Networks National Post The Province (Vancouver) Vancouver Sun Edmonton Journal Calgary Herald Regina Leader-Post Saskatoon StarPhoenix Windsor Star Ottawa Citizen Montreal Gazette Don't Miss: Happening Now Video Centre Live chats Blogs on canada.com canada.com on Facebook Oddities News Happening Now Local National World Oddities Photo Galleries Weather Business Money Markets Mortgages Sports Hockey NHL Video Highlights Football-CFL Football-NFL Baseball Basketball Winter Sports Golf Racing Soccer Tennis MMA Entertainment Celebrity Music Movies Television Books TV Listings Lifestyle Fashion & Beauty Food Parenting Relationships Astrology Health Diet & Fitness Sexual Health Seniors Family & Child Men Women Travel Destinations Technology Gaming Internet Tech-Biz Space Personal Tech         Canada grocers seen slowing market share loss to Costco, Walmart     By Aleksandra Sagan, The Canadian Press May 16, 2017     Story Photos ( 1 )     Customers push shopping carts at Costco in Mississauga, Ont., on Monday, May 15, 2017. While international retailers Costco and Walmart have gobbled up a growing share of Canadian food sales for more than a decade, further gains are expected to be tougher to eke out as the country's traditional grocers mount an improved defence. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Nathan Denette TORONTO — While international retailers Costco and Walmart have gobbled up a growing share of Canadian food sales for more than a decade, further gains are expected to be tougher to eke out as the country's traditional grocers mount an improved defence. Industry watchers say the price gap between the two sides has narrowed and the traditional stores' loyalty programs are helping support sales. "Every point of market share is hard fought over in the grocery market," said Kenric S. Tyghe, a consumer and retail analyst at Raymond James. "The traditional grocers have done a better job defending share than, I think, a lot of observers expected." While they have operated in Canada for years, competition from Costco and Walmart is still top of mind for local grocers given the low-cost strategy of the two foreign giants. In his most recent quarterly call with analysts in April, Metro CEO Eric R. La Fleche discussed Costco's expansion in Ontario, saying it is "a significant competitor, and we have to execute and differentiate." In the second quarter of 2004, traditional grocery stores sold about $12.3 billion worth of food, accounting for about 90 per cent of the market, according to Statistics Canada data. General merchandisers, which include Costco and Walmart, sold about $1.3 billion or roughly 9.8 per cent. In the same quarter of 2016, traditional grocers' market share fell to about 79.2 per cent, while that of the general merchandisers more than doubled. Those changes translate "into billions and billions of dollars every quarter," said Kevin Grier, an agriculture and food market analyst, adding that the shift in market share to the U.S. chains is expected to slow. "You can't keep that up," he said. Canadian grocers were granted some respite from foreign-owned competitors when Target, which entered the Canadian market in 2013, pulled out of the country in 2015. Costco now operates 95 warehouses in Canada, while Walmart runs 410 stores. Costco plans to open three more stores by the end of this year for a total of seven new stores in 2017. Spokesman Ron Damiani said that's the most sites the company's opened in a financial year in recent memory. While Walmart has not revealed any new expansion plans, it announced in 2015 it would add 42 supercentre locations. Tyghe said that pace of expansion will not create the sort of disruption and dislocation seen when growth in square footage at the two chains outpaced population increases, forcing Canadian grocers to lower prices. The traditional grocers have also boosted their discount banner store counts, Tyghe said, keeping their hold on the most price-oriented customers. Loblaw, for example, operates 500 discount banner stores, including No Frills, across Canada. "We believe we have some of the strongest, most effectively operated and most customer-centric discount formats in the country," Loblaw CEO Galen G. Weston said in an interview after the company's annual meeting earlier this month. For the average Canadian shopper, that means the price difference between a product at a traditional grocer and a Costco or Walmart is not necessarily compelling enough to justify shopping at two separate locations, Tyghe said. "You're not going to win on price alone," he said. Another factor favouring traditional grocers is their strong loyalty programs, which give them robust customer data and the ability to target promotional offers to individuals based on their shopping habits, Tyghe said. "How they respond is increasingly in a very data-driven, targeted, promotional way," he said. — With files from Linda Nguyen Follow @AleksSagan on Twitter.       E-mail this Article Print this Article Share this Article           Story Tools   E-mail this Article Print this Article Share this Article   Font: * * * * *   Image: * * * *       Customers push shopping carts at Costco in Mississauga, Ont., on Monday, May 15, 2017. While international retailers Costco and Walmart have gobbled up a growing share of Canadian food sales for more than a decade, further gains are expected to be tougher to eke out as the country's traditional grocers mount an improved defence. Celebrate with these grill deals from America’s top retailers. By Laura Woods | May 16, 2017 Kamil Macniak / Shutterstock.com National BBQ Day falls on May 16, serving as the perfect way to kick off summer grilling season. If you don’t currently own a grill or need an upgrade, now is the time to buy. The origins of National BBQ Day are a bit unclear, but there’s no need to question a holiday this delicious. Plenty of major retailers will be offering grill deals on the big day, so find out where to shop. Home Depot Take up to 15 percent off gas and charcoal grills through May 17. You’ll also get free shipping on all grills and free in-store assembly. Some of the top grill deals include: Monument Grills Four-Burner Propane Gas Grill in Stainless With LED Controls, Side Burner and Rotisserie Kit: $279.65. Vision Grills Kamado Professional Ceramic Charcoal Grill With Grill Cover in Chili Red, Orange, Taupe or White with Grill Cover: $599. Nexgrill Deluxe Six-Burner Propane Gas Grill in Stainless Steel With Ceramic Searing Side Burner and Ceramic Rotisserie Burner: $594.15. Don’t Miss: Secret Ways to Save Money at Home Depot Costco The big box retailer’s everyday low prices mean you can get a great bargain to celebrate National BBQ Day. Don’t miss these summer grilling deals: Homping Portable Charcoal Grill: $199.99. KitchenAid Eight-Burner Grill: $899.99. Urban Islands 304 Stainless Steel Four-Burner BBQ Cart by Bull Outdoor Products: $1,599.99. Shipping is included in the price of most items, so you won’t have to worry about hefty charges tacked onto your total. Some grills might also be available at your local Costco store. Walmart Celebrate National BBQ Day by taking advantage of limited-time grill deals at Walmart. Many of these summer grilling offers include free shipping, allowing you to save even more: Walmart Two-Burner LP Gas Grill: $95.32. Walmart Five-Burner Gas Grill: $156.07. Char-Broil Convective Six-Burner Grill: $292.48. Char-Broil Six-Burner Gas Grill With Sear: $299.98. Char-Broil 505 Sq. In. Charcoal/Gas Combo Grill, 1010 Deluxe: $319. Target For a limited time, save up to 20 percent on grills at Target. Some of these BBQ deals include: Stok Drum Charcoal Grill: $103.99. STK Gridiron Portable Gas Grill: $127.99. Char-Broil TRU-Infrared Two-Burner Gas Grill: $199.99. Dyna-Glo Two-Burner 30,000 BTU Smart Space Living LP Gas Grill: $223.99. Char-Broil Performance 550 Five-Burner Cabinet 45,000 BTU Gas Grill With Side Burner: $239.99. The store also offers free shipping and free returns on orders of $35 or more, allowing you to maximize your savings. Read: 25 Secret Ways to Save Money at Target Sears Just in time for National BBQ Day, Sears has several limited-time “Hot Deals” on grills, offering savings of up to 30 percent. Some of these BBQ deals include: Kenmore Deluxe Charcoal Grill: $197.99. Kenmore Four-Burner LP Mocha Gas Grill With Searing Side Burner: $277.19. Kenmore Five-Burner Gas Grill With Ceramic Searing and Rotisserie Burner: $544.49. KitchenAid 36-Inch Four-Burner Built-In Gas Grill With Ceramic Searing Burner and Rotisserie Burner: $999.99. Additionally, take an extra 10 percent off select grills with code 10SEARS through May 27. You can also score free home delivery on certain grill items priced $499 and up through July 31. Lowe’s Celebrate National BBQ Day by taking advantage of a 20-percent price drop on the Char-Broil 29.8-Inch Charcoal Grill, now $159. Lowe’s also offers free delivery on many grills, including: Weber Spirit E-310 Black Porcelain Enamel Three-Burner 32,000-BTU Liquid Propane Gas Grill: $499. Weber Genesis II Black Three-Burner 37,500-BTU Liquid Propane Gas Grill: $699. Weber Summit S-670 Six-Burner 60,000-BTU Liquid Propane Gas Grill With Side and Rotisserie Burners and Integrated Smoker Box: $2,499. Kmart Stop into your local Kmart through May 20, to take $25 off the BBQ Pro Two-Burner LP Gas Grill with Large Side Shelves, with a sale price of $89.99. If you’re shopping online, use code 10KMART to take 10 percent off grills purchased online through May 24. Up Next: 101 Ways to Save Money This Summer Prices are accurate as of May 15, 2017. Log In 1 of 3 Premium Clicks used this month Print + Online Subscriber Activation Register Subscribe News Sports Entertainment Life Obits E-Edition Autos Jobs Real Estate Classifieds log in New Bedford woman 'relieved' Walmart settlement approved Monday May 15, 2017 at 6:22 PM May 16, 2017 at 10:44 AM Jennette Barnes @jbarnesnews BOSTON — A U.S District Court judge has approved a $7.5 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit by a former Walmart employee who sued the retail giant for denying health insurance to her legal same-sex spouse. Jacqueline Cote of New Bedford was in court Monday to see Judge William G. Young approve the settlement, 14 months after Cote's wife, Diana “Dee” Smithson, died of ovarian cancer. The action is expected to finalize the settlement reached late last year. Smithson was diagnosed in 2012, and the couple began incurring significant medical bills. Cote sued in 2015, saying Walmart repeatedly denied her wife coverage in violation of the Civil Rights Act. The Arkansas-based company began offering benefits for same-sex spouses in 2014. Massachusetts had legalized same-sex marriage a decade earlier, in 2004. Monday's hearing was brief, lasting perhaps two or three minutes. Young said the settlement was "in all respects fair and reasonable." "This was a carefully crafted and sensitive resolution of a complex matter," he said during the hearing. Cote and others who can document out-of-pocket health-care costs of $60,000 or more will receive payouts of three times their expenses. A source close to the case said Cote's expenses totaled about $152,000, meaning she will receive about $456,000, plus court costs. Those who can document lesser expenses will receive payouts of 1.5 times their costs. In addition, Walmart "commits to treating same-sex and opposite-sex spouses or couples equally in the provision of health insurance benefits, so long as to do so in consistent with applicable law," according to the settlement agreement. A spokeswoman for GLAD said Cote and her attorneys had expected to receive permission from Walmart to speak to the press, but had not received it by the time of the hearing. Cote declined an interview for the same reason. In 2015, she told The Standard-Times that one of the many hard things about not being able to provide health care for her wife was attending Walmart's workplace diversity trainings every year.  “I absolutely wanted to scream,” she said. “The thing I wanted to scream was: ‘Show me the diversity.’” She said she never felt discrimination at the store level where she worked in Swansea. She was represented in court by lawyers from GLBTQ Legal Advocates and Defenders, or GLAD, and the firm Outten & Golden, which specializes in employment law. She was also represented in the case by the Washington Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights and Urban Affairs, and Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer. After the hearing, GLAD issued a news release with a quote from Cote: “I’m pleased that Walmart was willing to resolve this issue for me and other associates who are married to someone of the same sex. It’s a relief to bring this chapter of my life to a close.” GLAD called the agreement "an important settlement for LGBTQ workers," and Walmart said the company was "happy both sides could come together to reach a resolution," according to the press release. The settlement class is expected to include up to a few thousand current and former Walmart employees. Follow Jennette Barnes on Twitter @jbarnesnews. Skip to content MilTech PR Distribution Menu HOME Add the press release Our team & Contact Posted on 16 May 2017 by Maciej Heyman SalesWarp Releases Major Software Upgrades for Its Advanced Order Management System With our software, retailers can close the gap between customer expectations and retail execution. This latest product release represents our commitment to providing solutions that enable retailers to succeed in an increasingly hyper-competitive market. Baltimore, Maryland (PRWEB) May 16, 2017 SalesWarp, the retail industry’s premier provider of inventory, order, and fulfillment management solutions, today announced the latest release (3.0.8) of its cloud-based software. Key upgrades include new e-commerce platform integrations, additional marketplace coverage, expanded product catalog functionality, and enhanced fraud prevention. SalesWarp now supports integrations with Volusion, Zoey, and Walmart, expanding platform and channel options for retailers while providing all the necessary back-end tech support. That means no additional in-house systems or personnel required for a merchant to deploy or manage a new sales channel. With over 100 million unique monthly visits, Walmart.com represents a massive opportunity for retailers to increase their brand exposure and sales while also diversifying their online channels. Walmart is the second largest retail site online, boasting more than 35 million SKUs and 7,000 marketplace sellers. SalesWarp’s cloud-based solution allows merchants to efficiently automate and manage the online selling process across multiple channels, including third-party marketplaces like Amazon, eBay, and Walmart. “SalesWarp continues innovating smart features for sellers to easily and accurately handle any and all omnichannel retail challenges,” said David Potts, founder and CEO of SalesWarp. “With our software, retailers can close the gap between customer expectations and retail execution. This latest product release represents our commitment to providing solutions that enable retailers to succeed in an increasingly hyper-competitive market.” With SalesWarp’s 3.0.8 version, retailers with large product catalogs can instantly sift through hundreds of thousands of products, which makes the critical information management process much faster and far easier. Now, customers can scale their product listing pages without slowing down system performance or spending hours managing their listings. SalesWarp’s best-in-class advanced order management solution has also been updated to provide retailers better protection against security breaches and scams through increased fraud detection and prevention capabilities. Retailers can easily create security rules unique to their businesses, limiting vulnerabilities without sacrificing the buying experience for valued, legitimate customers. All the new features in SalesWarp’s latest release are implemented by the SalesWarp Team, as part of standard deployment and maintenance services. SalesWarp performs all necessary system installations and updates with an absolute minimum interruption to a retailer’s business. About SalesWarp SalesWarp is a distributed order management solution designed for retailers at every stage of growth. As the premier engine for omnichannel selling and fulfillment, with built-in business logic and powerful workflows, SalesWarp helps retailers manage operations and data more efficiently across their entire organization. Unmatched in scalability and performance, SalesWarp’s cloud-based software gives retailers the ability to meet both current and future customer demand, while optimizing operations to drive business growth and profitability. To learn more, visit SalesWarp at http://www.saleswarp.com. About Future Resources Staff Contact Privacy Policy Search for: Select Press Releases Home / Press Releases / SalesWarp Releases Major Software Upgrades for Its Advanced Order Management System SalesWarp Releases Major Software Upgrades for Its Advanced Order Management System Posted on May 16, 2017 by Benzinga Full Feed in Press Releases Leadership is an overused word, and is often misused. We like this definition. Retailers Gain Additional Sales Channel to Drive Business Growth Baltimore, Maryland (PRWEB) May 16, 2017 SalesWarp, the retail industry’s premier provider of inventory, order, and fulfillment management solutions, today announced the latest release (3.0.8) of its cloud-based software. Key upgrades include new e-commerce platform integrations, additional marketplace coverage, expanded product catalog functionality, and enhanced fraud prevention. SalesWarp now supports integrations with Volusion, Zoey, and Walmart, expanding platform and channel options for retailers while providing all the necessary back-end tech support. That means no additional in-house systems or personnel required for a merchant to deploy or manage a new sales channel. With over 100 million unique monthly visits, Walmart.com represents a massive opportunity for retailers to increase their brand exposure and sales while also diversifying their online channels. Walmart is the second largest retail site online, boasting more than 35 million SKUs and 7,000 marketplace sellers. SalesWarp’s cloud-based solution allows merchants to efficiently automate and manage the online selling process across multiple channels, including third-party marketplaces like Amazon, eBay, and Walmart. “SalesWarp continues innovating smart features for sellers to easily and accurately handle any and all omnichannel retail challenges,” said David Potts, founder and CEO of SalesWarp. “With our software, retailers can close the gap between customer expectations and retail execution. Retailers can easily create security rules unique to their businesses, limiting vulnerabilities without sacrificing the buying experience for valued, legitimate customers. All the new features in SalesWarp’s latest release are implemented by the SalesWarp Team, as part of standard deployment and maintenance services. SalesWarp performs all necessary system installations and updates with an absolute minimum interruption to a retailer’s business. Unmatched in scalability and performance, SalesWarp’s cloud-based software gives retailers the ability to meet both current and future customer demand, while optimizing operations to drive business growth and profitability. To learn more, visit SalesWarp at http://www.saleswarp.com. Share Tweet Share Email Comments CHIPPEWA FALLS — The Lake Hallie Police Department and Lake Hallie Village Board have requested that a lawsuit filed after an officer fatally shot a 25-year-old woman at a Walmart in April 2016 be dismissed.  Other entities being sued by the woman’s family are saying they intend to file similar motions. Melissa Abbott was a resident at the Northern Wisconsin Center, a state-operated facility for persons with disabilities and mental diseases. On April 8, 2016, Abbott was at the Walmart in Lake Hallie, 2786 Commercial Boulevard, when she began swinging a hatchet around other shoppers in the store. The Chippewa County dispatch center received a call at 5:11 p.m. about a “disorderly female who refused to leave the store.” Lake Hallie police Officer Adam Meyers arrived at the scene. Meyers shot twice, striking Abbott in the leg and abdomen. Abbott was taken to a nearby hospital, where she died. In May 2016, then-District Attorney Steve Gibbs issued a 12-page ruling, saying that Meyers “acted in self-defense and that his belief that he reasonably believed his life was in danger, or that he was likely to suffer great bodily harm, when Ms. Abbott refused to follow orders and charged officer Meyers with a hatchet.” However, the woman’s family filed the lawsuit earlier this year against the village, the store, the Police Department, the Northern Wisconsin Center and several insurance companies. Matteo Reginato, an attorney representing the village and the Police Department, filed a response earlier this month, requesting the lawsuit be dismissed. Reginato wrote that Meyers “acted consistent with his authority and within the scope of his employment at all times relevant to this lawsuit.” A telephone scheduling conference was Monday in Chippewa County Court before Judge James Isaacson. During that discussion, Wal-Mart’s attorney Angela Brandt informed Isaacson that her office also planned to file a motion to dismiss. “There aren’t any actual, factual allegations against Wal-Mart,” Brandt said. Other attorneys in the phone conference also expressed that they would be filing dismissal motions as well. Attorney Jeff Muszynski, who represents the Abbott family, told Isaacson that he is still working through mediation, and has not gotten to any exchange of discovery between the parties. Isaacson set another telephone scheduling conference for June 16, saying that should give Muszynski enough time to be prepared to move forward with court dates. The lawsuit, filed by River Falls attorney Dean Rohde, disagrees with Gibbs’ assessment of the incident. Rohde wrote that Meyers’ conduct and actions were “excessive and unreasonable, without lawful justification or reason, and was designed to and did cause specific and serious physical harm, pain and suffering and death.” He added that her death was caused by “the negligence of the village of Lake Hallie and or its agents and employees.” Rohde is requesting a jury award punitive damages to any and all defendants, that Lake Hallie, the Police Department, and the Northern Wisconsin Center “provide necessary training, personnel and resources to adequately protect the constitutional rights of citizens and patients of the Northern Wisconsin Center,” and that the defendants pay all attorney fees and other associated costs. Abbott was living at the Northern Wisconsin Center for the Developmentally Disabled on the east side of Chippewa Falls. The report includes interviews with workers at the facility, who had accompanied Abbott on the trip to Wal-Mart. Several other shoppers and Walmart employees also were interviewed. Gibbs report also included details about Abbott’s background in his report. “She has been diagnosed with depressive disorder, borderline personality disorder, and a mild intellectual disability,” Gibbs wrote. “She has been hospitalized in the past at Sacred Heart Hospital and Winnebago Mental Health Institute. Due to Melissa’s aggressive behaviors, multiple physical and mechanical restrains have been used to manage her challenging behaviors.” Abbott has threatened to kill the staff at the Excel Treatment Center, and wrote in her journal a desire that “when the cops get called I will grab their gun and there will be a shootout between me and the cops.” Meyers, who has been employed as a Lake Hallie police officer since Oct. 8, 2008, was placed on administrative leave after the shooting, which is standard protocol. Contact: 715-723-0303, chris.vetter@ecpc.com Tagged: Walmart shooting, Chippewa County Court, Steve Gibbs Click to comment Close comments Related CF man convicted of hurting infant Labrec sentenced to 20 years’ prison in Patterson murder case Plea entered for 9th OWI Man gets jail for failing to register as sex offender Front Page Twister kills 1, hurts 25 in Barron County Sports Baseball: Huskies clinch share of BRC with win over Abes Front Page Path well taken: Run/walk fundraiser during Broiler Festival will benefit planned expansion of trail at Eleva Lake Park Front Page Religions receive little study from school districts in region © 2017 Leader-Telegram, Eau Claire, WI. All rights reserved. To Top Applying filter…
Home Subscribe (Free) About NaturalNews Contact Us Write for NaturalNews Media info Advertising info ARTICLES BLOGS LABS SCIENCE REFERENCE REPORTS VIDEOS RADIO INFOGRAPHICS MUSIC CARTOONS LIBRARY RSS STORE Search Powered by GoodGopher.com More children harmed by VACCINES than from GUNSHOTS Govt. says OK to death-threat "anti-vaxxers" Diabetic prepper? This may be the most important article you ever read Monday, May 15, 2017 by: Jayson Veley Tags: diabetes, insulin, prepping, survival (Natural News) Whether it’s the result of an EMP strike, a nuclear attack or some kind of zombie apocalypse, people across the country are vigorously preparing for life after society collapses like a house of cards. Many Americans have spent thousands of dollars on underground bunkers that they can retreat to should the outside world become too dangerous. Others have spent weeks planning out elaborate escape routes and rendezvous points so that they will have a place to meet up with family and friends should traditional transportation become impossible. But while this is all well and good, what is someone supposed to do if they have a condition that requires society to be intact in order to obtain the necessary treatment? According to the Centers for Disease Control, 29.1 million Americans had diagnosed or undiagnosed diabetes as of the year 2014, a number equal to 9.3 percent of the population. [RELATED: Read about the top five natural substances that could cure type 1 diabetes]. If someone who is living with diabetes is dependent on insulin, then the financial burden can be quite harsh, considering the fact that vials of insulin can cost $200 to $300 each. So, if the entire economy collapses along with society itself, how is a diabetic supposed to survive in a post-apocalyptic world? If you are a diabetic, the best way to handle being in a life or death situation such as the one described above is to not put yourself in that situation to begin with. A world without insulin as a diabetic would undoubtedly be extremely challenging, so the best thing anyone can do is prepare ahead of time and take precautionary measures. A few weeks ago, a contributor to The Survivalist Blog described a scenario in which he was talking to his doctor about the overwhelming cost of insulin. Much to his surprise, the doctor informed him that Walmart sells insulin over-the-counter without any questions asked for as little as $28. The doctor said that all he had to do was go to a Walmart pharmacy and ask for a vial of Novolin R insulin, a solution identical to the more expensive Humulin R, which costs roughly $150 per bottle. Better still, Walmart pharmacies that sell over-the-counter insulin allow consumers to purchase up to four vials at a time, providing diabetic preppers with an incredible opportunity to stock up in a relatively short amount of time. Many Walmart stores even sell other diabetic care products, such as syringes, meters and test strips, all of which are inexpensive and easy to purchase. The downside, however, is that not all states allow Walmart stores to sell insulin over-the-counter. People are encouraged to check online or visit their local Walmart shopping centers for more information. As with the purchase of any other medication, it is still important to know that what you are putting into your body is safe. Carmen Smith of Cleveland was another diabetic who eventually realized that she could purchase insulin from Walmart at a much lower cost and without a prescription. However, unlike the contributor for the Survivalist Blog, Smith didn’t have nearly as smooth an experience. Unsure of the correct dose, Smith used the amount a doctor had prescribed her years before. Describing what it was like when she didn’t get the dose of her insulin injections correct, she said, “It’s a quick high and then, it’s a down. The down part is, you feel icky. You feel lifeless. You feel pain. And the cramps are so intense — till you can’t walk, you can’t sit, you can’t stand.” She went on to say that because she was forced to guess how much insulin she should inject herself with, Smith had to visit the emergency room a number of times over the following years. Still, the fact that many Walmart stores sell non-prescription insulin is a little known fact that may very well help millions of diabetic preppers across the country. Walmart settles $7.5 million in lawsuit for denying same-sex couples health benefits · PinkNews Enter your email address to receive our daily LGBT news roundup Sign up No thanks You're free to unsubscribe at any time. Follow @pinknews News News Home UK US World Trans Politics Education Law Religion Business Entertainment Trans Opinion Travel Life Life Home Health Sport About Advertise Contact Privacy RSS Search Home UK US World Current Affairs Entertainment Opinion Travel Features Trans US Walmart settles $7.5 million in lawsuit for denying same-sex couples health benefits Joseph Patrick McCormick, PinkNews 16th May 2017, 12:02 AM The money will be split in the class action lawsuit Walmart on Monday has had a $7.5 million settlement approved in a class action lawsuit alleging that same-sex couples were denied equal health benefits. The lawsuit was filed on behalf of a woman from New Bedford by GLAAD. It was based on the US Supreme Court ruling which extended marriage to same-sex couples across all 50 states, and an earlier ruling which extended spousal benefits to all couples. Jacqueline Cote had worked at Walmart for 15 years an initiated the lawsuit, but more than 300 other couples joined the suit making it class action. The plaintiffs will split $5.5 million between them, as attorneys’ fees will be deducted. US District Judge William G Young said the amount is fair for the lawsuit. “This was a carefully crafted and sensible resolution of a complex matter, and it reflects well on the parties from both sides,” Young said, speaking from the bench on Monday. Wal-Mart back in December agreed to pay out $7.5 million to settle the lawsuit. Employees complained that by failing to extend health insurance benefits to cover their partners, they were being discriminated against. Over a thousand current and former workers were affected by the policy which denied same-sex couples heath benefits between 2011 and 2013. The lawsuit was filed not long after same-sex marriage became legal across the US, in July 2015. Cote’s own wife had over $150,000 in bills fighting ovarian cancer, and so the lawsuit sought out reparations for before the policy was introduced. She said in a statement on Monday: “I’m pleased that Walmart was willing to resolve this issue for me and other associates who are married to someone of the same sex. It’s a relief to bring this chapter of my life to a close.” Sally Welborn, senior vice president for the company, said in a statement: “We’re happy both sides could come together to reach a resolution . . . We will continue to not distinguish between same and opposite sex spouses when it comes to the benefits we offer under our health insurance plan.” Walmart last year ditched a transphobic Halloween costume that was being sold via its online store. Ahead of Halloween the US supermarket giant was stocking a so-called ‘Tranny Granny’ costume via its online marketplace. 0 reader comments Share on Facebook Share on Twitter More like this Ellen surprised this hilarious teacher who pranked students with a RuPaul inspired spelling test Ellen DeGeneres just paid for an entire class of high school students to go to college (VIDEO) Walmart to pay out $7.5 million in lawsuit which denied gay couples equal health benefits Gerard Butler criticised for bizarre, ‘homophobic’ Halloween costume Walmart withdraws ‘appalling’ Tranny Granny Halloween costume More: supreme court same sex couples lawsuit GLAAD walmart health benefits class action Trending Trending Now Big Bang Theory's Jim Parsons marries Arrested Development star comes out Check out these adorable pics from Big Bang Theory Jim Parsons’ wedding Transgender woman killed, dismembered and cooked in a broth by her chef husband Trending The Big Bang Theory’s Jim Parsons marries his long-term boyfriend Arrested Development star comes out as bisexual Check out these adorable pics from Big Bang Theory Jim Parsons’ wedding This chef killed and dismembered his transgender wife before cooking her in a broth Latest stories Louisiana advances bill to protect same-sex couples in domestic abuse cases Abby Wambach and Glennon Doyle Melton just announced they are married Nevada bill to let trans people change names privately passes unanimously Trans man who overcame legal name change battle dies aged 25 Non-binary couple face vile Facebook abuse ahead of Good Morning Britain appearance LGBT group takes case against anti-Pride t-shirt printer to state Supreme Court © 2017 PinkNews Terms Contact Advertise

Special Reports Videos Photo Galleries Utah Bucket List Preparing to play Money Top Workplaces Home Prices Obituaries Jobs Top Employer Top Educator Top Jobs Employment News Employers Post A Job Contact Us    SPONSORED BY: Homes Find a Home Find a Realtor Rentals Legal Notices Top Workplaces Subscribe    Print New Subscription Register for e-Edition Access your e-Edition Print Registration Print Login    sltrib.com Membership Become a Supporting Member Premium Ad-Free Site Login Account Login Member FAQ Home » News Salt Lake City 58 ° Traffic / Ski Report Stories from last 36 hours 2017 PULITZER PRIZE WINNER 2017 PULITZER PRIZE WINNER MAY 17, 2017 MAY 17, 2017 Become a Member | Ad-Free Login Home » News MAY 17, 2017  |  Salt Lake City 58 °  |  Traffic / Ski Report Stories from last 36 hours Become a Member | Ad-Free Login Home » News Become a Member | Ad-Free Login $7.5M settlement approved in Wal-Mart same-sex benefits case The Associated Press First Published May 15 2017 07:30PM    •    Last Updated May 15 2017 07:30 pm Share This Article Boston • A $7.5 million class action settlement between Wal-Mart and a former employee who challenged the retail chain's lack of health insurance benefits for her same-sex spouse was approved by a federal judge on Monday. The settlement will pay current and former Wal-Mart associates in the U.S. and Puerto Rico who say they were unable to obtain health insurance for their same-sex spouses from 2011 to 2013. About 380 claims have been submitted. U.S. District Judge William Young approved the settlement after a brief hearing in federal court in Boston. The lawsuit was filed in 2015 by Jacqueline Cote, a Wal-Mart associate from Massachusetts who said the company denied medical insurance for her wife. Bentonville, Ark.-based Wal-Mart Stores Inc. began offering benefits for same-sex spouses in 2014. VIDEOS TOP JOBS Cote, whose wife died of ovarian cancer in 2016, said she was pleased Wal-Mart was willing to resolve the issue for her and other associates who are married to someone of the same sex. "It's a relief to bring this chapter of my life to a close," she said. Wal-Mart's senior vice president for global benefits, Sally Welborn, said the company was happy to resolve the case.   Share This Article JOIN THE DISCUSSION     Post a Comment POPULAR STORIES KUTV anchor returns to air, issues apology after DUI arrest Interactive Mormon genealogy exhibit plays to cultural stereotypes, critics argue Utah's Chaffetz says he will subpoena Comey memo if necessary FLDS town evictions set up a sad spectacle Kragthorpe: Gordon Hayward will stay with Jazz, unless Celtics rise in East ELEVATE 8 inspection pitfalls to avoid when buying a home   An Insider’s Guide to Lava Hot Springs   Contests and Promotions COMMENTS VIEW/POST COMMENT      () News All Local News Search Last 36 hours Nation + World RSS Twitter Environment Politics Justice Polygamy Education Weather Traffic Utah's Right Elevate Empower Utah Cool Stuff The Legacy of Joe Hill I Love videos Whatever Happened To...
