More on Maternity and Birthing Environment Roundups Environment On World Water Day, a Spotlight on U.S. Public Water Systems Mar 22, 2016 Kanya D’Almeida Trending on Environment Judicial Announcements Show Conservatives Coming for Abortion Rights Why We Must Not Forget Standing Rock Florida Residents Concerned About Possible Effects of Pipeline on Their Health More on Environment Sections Search Rewire Lawsuit: Walmart Discriminated Against Pregnant Workers May 17, 2017 Subscribe Donate Your Reading List Lawsuit: Walmart Discriminated Against Pregnant Workers One in Six Women Will Lose Under GOP Health Policy Author Jill Filipovic on the Radical Notion That Women Deserve Pleasure and Joy Search Rewire Go News Law and Policy Lawsuit: Walmart Discriminated Against Pregnant Workers May 15, 2017, 6:18pm Nicole Knight “Pregnancy discrimination is a huge problem that disproportionately affects low-wage workers, like those at Walmart," said Dina Bakst of A Better Balance. Facebook Twitter Email Permalink Instapaper Print Two female Walmart workers claim the company denied them pregnancy-related accommodations. Joe Raedle/Getty Images Trending Today This Week DNC Chair Tom Perez to Meet With Anti-Choice Democrats The Descent of Anti-Choice Radicals on Louisville Is a Preview of Protests to Come ‘Fringe’ Republican in Montana Congressional Race Faces Close Contest Betsy DeVos’ Choice of New Hires Suggests She’ll Keep Her School Privatization Promises Haitian Immigrants Rally in Protest of Possible Deportations Gavel Drop: California, Texas in the Hot Seat for Voting Violations Despite Trump’s Claims of Victory, the Little Sisters’ Fight Against Birth Control Continues Lawsuit: Walmart Discriminated Against Pregnant Workers What DOJ’s Rod Rosenstein Could Learn From the Man He Helped Fire What the New Health-Care Bill Means for Chronically Ill People Like Me and Our Families The Descent of Anti-Choice Radicals on Louisville Is a Preview of Protests to Come Meet the People Trumpcare Hurts the Most Nebraska Democrat With Anti-Choice Record Loses Mayoral Bid The Abortion Story I Didn’t Expect to Tell DNC Chair Tom Perez to Meet With Anti-Choice Democrats Betsy DeVos’ Choice of New Hires Suggests She’ll Keep Her School Privatization Promises Religious Imposition Laws Religious imposition laws are designed to shield private individuals and businesses from complying with nondiscrimination laws based on a religious objection to that service. Two former Walmart employees last week filed a class action lawsuit in federal court, claiming the retail giant discriminated against them and thousands of pregnant workers by failing to provide on-the-job accommodations. The lawsuit alleges that while the $231 billion company makes on-the-job accommodations to many non-pregnant workers, Walmart fails to accommodate pregnant workers. Walmart’s policies and practices, according to the 25-page complaint, amount to “intentional discrimination.” Walmart employs nearly 1.2 million people in the United States, 784,000 of whom are women, according to the complaint and a 2015 company report. The suit was brought by two former Walmart workers who became pregnant while employed at Walmart stores in Illinois and Florida. Both workers filed discrimination complaints against Walmart with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and state agencies, according to the complaint. Appreciate our work? Rewire is a non-profit independent media publication. Your tax-deductible contribution helps support our research, reporting, and analysis. DONATE NOW Otisha Woolbright, a former bakery and deli clerk in Florida, claims she was terminated because of her pregnancy and need for pregnancy-related accommodations, according to the complaint. Woolbright told her supervisor her doctor had said to avoid any heavy lifting. Woolbright claims her supervisor told her she had seen a pregnant Demi Moore do a somersault on television, and pregnancy was therefore “no excuse.” It wasn’t until Woolbright went to the hospital after lifting a 35-pound tray of rotisserie chickens that the company allowed her to do sedentary work, according to the complaint. She was later let go after asking about pregnancy leave. While working at an Illinois Walmart, Talisa Borders was refused pregnancy accommodations when she showed her employer a doctor’s note saying she could not lift more than 25 pounds or climb ladders, according to the complaint. Borders claims a Walmart human resources training coordinator, who reviewed her request for accommodations, forced Borders to take more than two months of unpaid leave, rather than accommodate her pregnancy. When Borders returned to work after having a baby, she was assigned a job that paid $8.85 per hour—$2 less than her previous job in Walmart’s Pharmacy Department, the complaint alleges. Walmart spokesman Randy Hargrove said the company’s policies have always fully met or exceeded state and federal law, and its anti-discrimination policy offers more protection than the law requires. “That policy has long listed pregnancy as a protected status,” Hargrove, senior director of national media relations, said in an email to Rewire. “We deny the claims of Ms. Borders and Ms. Woolbright and plan to defend the company.” Walmart revised its written policy in 2014 to offer accommodations for temporary disabilities caused by pregnancy. But it did so only after pregnant workers filed a complaint with the EEOC alleging the company’s policy amounted to pregnancy discrimination, as Rewire reported. Attorneys who brought the suit said Walmart’s policies and practices continue to force pregnant people to choose between a job and a pregnancy. “In 2017, it’s incredible that major companies like Walmart are discriminating against pregnant women—who are simply asking to keep on working and have a healthy pregnancy,” said Dina Bakst, co-president of A Better Balance, one of the groups that filed the complaint. “Pregnancy discrimination is a huge problem that disproportionately affects low-wage workers, like those at Walmart.” Walmart has prevailed in class-action decisions, showing it’s difficult to hold corporations accountable in these types of cases, as Rewire reported. The U.S. Supreme Court in Wal-Mart v. Dukes revoked the class-action certification of female Walmart workers, who alleged the retailer engaged in unlawful discrimination in pay and promotions. The Court found the women didn’t have enough to hold them in common in their claims against Walmart. Updated: May 17, 2017 @ 1:35 am Full Forecast News Sports Obituaries Opinion Buy & Sell AP Chinese customers can now order from US Sam's Club stores By ANNE D'INNOCENZIO AP Retail Writer May 15, 2017 0 NEW YORK (AP) — Wal-Mart is letting online customers in China order from its Sam's Club stores in the U.S. for the first time to cater to China's increasingly affluent, well-traveled shoppers. It's Wal-Mart's latest attempt to boost growth in China since it sold its online business in the country to JD, China's No. 2 e-commerce site, in June 2016. The U.S. retailer has a 12 percent stake in JD and hopes working with the homegrown company will boost its performance in China. Getting China right is key to bolstering Wal-Mart's global online business. About 200 products from Sam's Clubs stores will initially be available for Sam's Club customers in China to order online via JD's website, expanding to 700 this year, says Rebecca Lui, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman. The company is focusing on personal care, baby supplies and nutritional supplies that are mostly not available in China. Products for sale include Aveeno moisturizers and Waterpik Ultra and Cordless Plus Water Flossers. Sam's Club has sold products on JD.com since October 2016, drawn from the stock in its 15 physical stores in China. Wal-Mart itself also operates more than 400 stores in China. The company is also tweaking its partnership with JD's delivery service, Daojia, to guarantee one-hour delivery, down from two hours, and expanding the number of stores where delivery is available. It expects to reach 180 stores this year. Get news headlines sent daily to your inbox Sign Up! It's Wal-Mart's latest attempt to boost growth in China since it sold its online business in the country to JD, China's No. 2 e-commerce site, in June 2016. The U.S. retailer has a 12 percent stake in JD and hopes working with the homegrown company will boost its performance in China. Getting China right is key to bolstering Wal-Mart's global online business. About 200 products from Sam's Clubs stores will initially be available for Sam's Club customers in China to order online via JD's website, expanding to 700 this year, says Rebecca Lui, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman. The company is focusing on personal care, baby supplies and nutritional supplies that are mostly not available in China. Sam's Club has sold products on JD.com since October 2016, drawn from the stock in its 15 physical stores in China. Wal-Mart itself also operates more than 400 stores in China. The company is also tweaking its partnership with JD's delivery service, Daojia, to guarantee one-hour delivery, down from two hours, and expanding the number of stores where delivery is available. It expects to reach 180 stores this year. It’s Wal-Mart’s latest attempt to boost growth in China since it sold its online business in the country to JD, China’s No. 2 e-commerce site, in June 2016. The U.S. retailer has a 12 percent stake in JD and hopes working with the homegrown company will boost its performance in China. Getting China right is key to bolstering Wal-Mart’s global online business. About 200 products from Sam’s Clubs stores will initially be available for Sam’s Club customers in China to order online via JD’s website, expanding to 700 this year, says Rebecca Lui, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman. The company is focusing on personal care, baby supplies and nutritional supplies that are mostly not available in China. Products for sale include Aveeno moisturizers and Waterpik Ultra and Cordless Plus Water Flossers. Sam’s Club has sold products on JD.com since October 2016, drawn from the stock in its 15 physical stores in China. Wal-Mart itself also operates more than 400 stores in China. The company is also tweaking its partnership with JD’s delivery service, Daojia, to guarantee one-hour delivery, down from two hours, and expanding the number of stores where delivery is available. It expects to reach 180 stores this year. It’s Wal-Mart’s latest attempt to boost growth in China since it sold its online business in the country to JD, China’s No. 2 e-commerce site, in June 2016. The U.S. retailer has a 12 percent stake in JD and hopes working with the homegrown company will boost its performance in China. Getting China right is key to bolstering Wal-Mart’s global online business. About 200 products from Sam’s Clubs stores will initially be available for Sam’s Club customers in China to order online via JD’s website, expanding to 700 this year, says Rebecca Lui, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman. The company is focusing on personal care, baby supplies and nutritional supplies that are mostly not available in China. Products for sale include Aveeno moisturizers and Waterpik Ultra and Cordless Plus Water Flossers. Sam’s Club has sold products on JD.com since October 2016, drawn from the stock in its 15 physical stores in China. The company is also tweaking its partnership with JD’s delivery service, Daojia, to guarantee one-hour delivery, down from two hours, and expanding the number of stores where delivery is available. It expects to reach 180 stores this year. CDT May 16, 2017 Austin police searching for armed intruders believed to be at St. Edward's main campus. CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST ARMED INTRUDER ON ST. EDWARD'S CAMPUS - Editor's Note: St. Edward's Campus Safety initially reported that armed intruders were on the main campus. Austin police later said there is no evidence that anyone was on campus. St. Edward's University campus was temporarily shut down Tuesday evening while police searched for suspects involved in an incident near a Walmart close to campus. Austin police said that the incident happened near the Walmart when two individuals met up to discuss a transaction and had a disagreement. Further details are not yet available, but APD said that there is no evidence that any shots were fired. APD looking for two suspects regarding incident that occurred near Walmart. Police searching the area near the garage. Stay indoors!— SEU Campus Safety (@SEUSafety) May 16, 2017 Around 7 p.m. APD said they were no longer searching for the suspects but believe that one of them may be known to officers. They are continuing the investigation with possible evidence recovered from the scene. APD said there is no threat to the public. © 2017 KVUE-TV CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST JOIN THE CONVERSATION To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Leave a Comment TRENDING VIDEOS VERIFY: Is Hobby Lobby closing? (REUTERS/Rebecca Cook)    Video Released Of Wal-Mart Shopper Tackling Legal Gun Owner [VIDEO] Chuck Ross Reporter 6:35 PM 01/21/2015      Pinterest  Reddit  LinkedIn  WhatsApp     Share         TOP Video footage taken from a Florida Wal-Mart shows a shopper literally jumping the gun. The surveillance footage, released by the Hillsborough County Sheriff’s Office on Wednesday, shows Michael Foster, 43, tackling Clarence Daniels from behind as he was walking into a Brandon, Fla. Wal-Mart on Tuesday. Foster followed Daniels into the store after seeing him exiting his vehicle with a gun holstered under his shirt — which was perfectly legal for the 62-year-old Daniels to do since he holds a concealed weapon license. Nevertheless, Foster tackled Daniels from behind as he entered the store, and put him in a chokehold before taking him to the ground. Witnesses said that Foster yelled out that Daniels had a gun. They also said that Daniels yelled out that he had a license for it. Foster called 911 only after he tackled accosted Daniels. He was arrested and charged with battery. Newsy0:42 UP NEXT Video by CBS Minnesota For years, Target Corp. had bragging rights over Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in at least one area: cachet. Quotes in the article Wal-Mart Stores Inc WMT ▼ 75.11 -1.18 -1.55% Target Corp TGT ▼ 54.53 -0.82 -1.48% Amazon.com Inc AMZN ▲ 966.07 +8.10 +0.85% McDonald's Corp MCD ▲ 147.29 +1.01 +0.69% With its sleek products and trendy designers, the company had an edge over Wal-Mart’s bland supercenters, and developed a cult following among customers. That was then. The tumult in U.S. retail with the rise of digital commerce has upended the industry’s natural pecking order, and one casualty has been Target’s cool factor. By a host of measures -- sales, share price, even intellectual property -- Wal-Mart is besting Target with cleaner stores, lower prices and a refurbished online strategy. “This is not your father’s Wal-Mart anymore,” said Chuck Grom, an analyst at Gordon Haskett Research Advisors. As the two retailers prepare to report first-quarter results this week, here’s how they stack up. The rivals’ divergent paths are perhaps best illustrated by same-store sales, a key industry metric. While Wal-Mart’s so-called “comps” have accelerated in recent quarters, Target’s have fallen into negative territory. And they aren’t likely to improve anytime soon, as the company has forecast a low-single digit decline for the full year. Wal-Mart’s sales, in contrast, may rise even further if food deflation subsides, according to Grom, since it generates more than half of its sales from the grocery aisles, compared with more than 20 percent for Target. Another reason for Target’s struggles is that its shoppers just aren’t buying as much, thanks to the growing appeal of online merchants such as Amazon.com Inc., which has made an aggressive push into apparel, a key category for Target. Amazon was the most highly regarded womenswear retailer in the U.S. based on affordability and authenticity, according to a survey from British trend tracker WGSN, while Target was eighth. Load Error In the most recent holiday quarter, the value of the average basket of goods at Target declined. Amazon, meantime, surpassed all other brick-and-mortar retailers as the most-popular shopping destination, according to researcher Kantar Retail. To get shoppers spending more, Target plans to introduce a dozen new exclusive brands, hoping to mimic the success of kids’ clothing line Cat & Jack, whose sales now approach $1 billion. It’s also testing next-day delivery of household staples like detergent and paper towels. “Target has lower penetration than Wal-Mart, so they have to get more out of their shoppers,” said Leon Nicholas, an analyst at Kantar. Wal-Mart, meanwhile, is rolling out curbside pickup of online grocery orders to 500 additional U.S. stores this year, eyeing busy suburban moms who don’t want to schlep around a cavernous big-box store. On a recent weekday morning at a Wal-Mart in Rogers, Arkansas, employees began walking the aisles to prepare online orders at 4 a.m. Outside the store, about 10 parking spaces were dedicated for curbside pickup. The company studied fast-food purveyors like McDonald’s Corp. to figure out the best layout for the pickup area. “For Wal-Mart, winning online grocery is mission critical,” said Robin Sherk, an analyst at Kantar. “There’s a lot of work to do there, but online grocery is probably working the best for them.” Target, following the 2013 data breach that exposed personal information of tens of millions of customers, ramped up promotional deals to lure shoppers back in the door. But such deals lead to price tags that swing up and down, confusing shoppers. Wal-Mart has invested billions to reduce its already low everyday prices to battle the encroachment of German hard-discount chains Aldi and Lidl, with a goal of being 15 percent cheaper than the competition on 80 percent of what it sells, according to an internal document obtained by Bloomberg. The result is a widening price gap between Wal-Mart and Target. Wal-Mart is also winning the intellectual property race. During the past five years, it has taken the lead over Target in patent applications, many focused on web development and easing shoppers’ journey through the store. The company has even filed a patent for in-store drones that would ferry products from the backroom to the sales floor. Target’s patents tend to deal with products, display units and shelving, according to researcher CB Insights. Over the past year, the company has jettisoned several long-term innovation projects to focus on its core business, and parted ways with its chief innovation and strategy officer and its chief digital officer. To contact the reporter on this story: Matthew Boyle in New York at mboyle20@bloomberg.net.  To contact the editors responsible for this story: Nick Turner at nturner7@bloomberg.net, Lisa Wolfson  ©2017 Bloomberg L.P. The first locations are set to open their doors in the next few weeks. As a result, Walmart is asking suppliers to keep their prices low, according to the Consumerist.    According to the report, vendors have been told that Walmart should be paying 15% less than competitors at least 80% of the time. Additionally, the retail giant is asking suppliers to ship Walmart’s orders complete and on time, which would help keep items in stock, avoid unneeded re-orders, and take in an additional $1 billion in sales — a move that would benefit suppliers, as well.   Lidl is not a new competitor for Walmart. The retail giant’s Asda stores compete directly against Lidl and Aldi in Europe. As Lidl prepares its U.S. debut, however, Walmart is eager stay one step ahead — especially since its European Asda brand has failed to grow sales for 13 consecutive quarters, while Lidl, along with Aldi, have captured 12% of the market, the report said.   To read more, click here.   Login or Register to post a comment. ﻿ Newsletter Sign Up Get the latest news sent to your inbox   Popular Most Commented Study ranks America’s favorite grocery stores Specialty apparel retailer exiting Canada Coach snags rival in $2.4 billion acquisition Jet.com ventures into physical retail Report: Children’s clothing retailer to reorganize President-elect hurting traffic at some major retail flagships Dollar Tree comes out on top Restaurant giant in $1.8 billion acquisition German grocery giant to make a big U.S. debut ahead of schedule Study: Retailers leave money on table due to lack of personalized service Solutions Spotlight Taking Stock of Retail’s Analytics Capabilities When it comes to using data and analytics to drive business results, where does the retail industry stand relative to other industries? Man used phone app to entice teen for sex - Erie News Now: News, Weather & Sports | WICU 12 & WSEE Member Center: Create Account| Log In Manage Account| Log Out SITE SEARCHWEB SEARCH BY Video Gallery Social Stream EVENTS 2017 Erie Mayoral Forum Email News/Apps Text Alerts LIVE Nat'l News Radar NewsNow MeTV CNN Video Social Stream Money Radar NewsNow NBC LIVE Nat'l News CNN Video CBS National/World EVENTS The Insider Real Estate Election 2017 Erie Mayoral Forum Email News/Apps School closings Korea Veterans Radar Web Cams Traffic/Airport Email News/Apps School closings EVENTS See It, Shoot It Text Alerts Web Cams - Local Roads Buoy Data Prep Champs EVENTS Text Alerts Golf Contest BBall Challenge Watch NBC Sports LIVE Golf Fashion Friday WICU TV Guide What's On NBC MeTV Watch CBS Food Winey Wednesday WSEE TV Listings NBC Mr. Food Contest Wine 2017 Erie Mayoral Forum Radar Giving You The Business Pump Pricer School closings MeTV EVENTS See It, Shoot It The Insider Text Alerts National Car and Truck Care Month Earth Day Across the Country Korea Veterans Local business Real Estate Transfers Wine Real Estate Closings Obituaries Great Deals! FAQ Digital Advertising Email News/Apps Wine News Team Contact Us Feedback Suggestions Jobs EEO Report Caribbean Main Entertainment Money Home/Family Health Food Pets Tech Travel Beauty & Style Auto VideoBytes Press Releases Man used phone app to entice teen for sex Posted: Tuesday, May 16, 2017 3:06 PM EDT Updated: Tuesday, May 16, 2017 3:06 PM EDT Joseph Wenzel IV WEST HARTFORD, CT -- A former educator at Wesleyan University was arrested after police said he attempted to entice a minor for sex. Police said West Hartford resident Scott Backer had been talking to who he thought was a 15-year-old girl on the phone app Yik Yak earlier this year. Backer had asked the "teen" to meet him at the Walmart in Cromwell. However, the teen was, in fact, an adult male posing as a teenage girl online. The man confronted Backer at Walmart on Jan. 12, where he videotaped their encounter. Police arrested Backer on Monday and charged with use of a computer to entice a minor to engage in sexual activity. He is being held on a $150,000 bond. Backer was fired from Wesleyan University last year after an investigation uncovered allegations of other sexual misconduct at his previous job at Vermont Academy, which is a college preparatory school. Backer's is the second arrest that can be directly attributed to the prey on predators website. A video of Baker was posted to Popsquadcc.com. Backer was arrested three months after his video was posted on the site. "It's a big relief, I feel like change is beginning to be made," POP Squad Founder Incognito said. Incognito said he wants his identity protected, so he can keep shining the light on local predators. For the past four months, Incognito has used his site to catch 40 suspects and had made a catch as recent as 2:30 a.m. on Tuesday. "People I didn't catch live, just on the chat logs, whether they were out of state, out of the country, well over 120," Incognito said. However, police said what Incognito is doing is dangerous and wish he'd leave it up to the trained professionals. "You never know how they're going to react," West Hartford Police Sgt. Tony Anderle said. "Are they going to run away? Are they going to attack you?" Even though some would think pop squad is gift-wrapping cases for police, detectives told Eyewitness News it's not always that cut and dry. "That turns into problems when if you're going to turn that over to police with judicial problems," Anderle said. "There's reasons there's police officers in your neighborhood." Incognito told Eyewitness News he has no plans to stop and his goal is to ultimately make penalties for local offenders as strong and severe as possible. MyNewMarkets.com Claims Journal Insurance Journal TV Academy of Insurance Carrier Management Featured Stories Florida Fails to Pass AOB Reform Wells Fargo to Sell Insurance Unit News Markets Jobs Front Page National International Most Popular Magazine Forums Blogs Videos/Podcasts Newsletters News Most Popular National International East Midwest South Central Southeast West Topics P&C Companies Agents & Brokers Government Markets/Coverages Operations Claims More Topics Magazines East Midwest South Central Southeast West Subscribe Research Directories Jobs Sales Marketing Management Finance Claims Underwriting Other Features Events Forums Buyers Guide Insurance Twitter Market Directories Ad Showcase Quotes Polls Subscribe Wal-Mart Denies Discrimination Claims by Pregnant Workers By Daniel Wiessner | May 16, 2017 Email This Print Newsletters Tweet Article 1 Comments Two former Wal-Mart Stores Inc. employees have filed a lawsuit accusing the retailer of treating thousands of pregnant workers as “second-class citizens” by rejecting their requests to limit heavy lifting, climbing on ladders and other potentially dangerous tasks. The proposed class action lawsuit was filed in federal court in Illinois on Friday by Talisa Borders and Otisha Woolbright, who say that until 2014, Arkansas-based Wal-Mart had a companywide policy that denied pregnant women the same accommodations as workers with other disabilities. The class could include at least 20,000 women and possibly up to 50,000 who worked at Wal-Mart while pregnant before the policy change, according to the lawsuit. The company in a statement provided by spokesman Randy Hargrove denied the women’s claims and said Wal-Mart’s pregnancy policies “have always fully met or exceeded both state and federal law.” The company said a separate anti-discrimination policy it maintains has long listed pregnancy as a protected status. “Walmart is a great place for women to work,” the company said. Borders and Woolbright say that Wal-Mart’s old policy violated a federal law requiring employers to treat pregnancy as a temporary disability and provide work accommodations to pregnant women. The U.S. Supreme Court, in a 2015 case involving United Parcel Service, said employers cannot treat pregnant workers differently from those with other disabilities or medical conditions. Wal-Mart, the largest private U.S. employer, changed its policy in 2014 to treat pregnancy as a disability. But lawyers for the plaintiffs in the lawsuit say the changes did not go far enough, and they were planning a separate lawsuit involving the new policy. Woolbright says her manager at a Florida Wal-Mart told her pregnancy was “no excuse” for not doing heavy lifting. She says she was fired from her job in the deli department after injuring herself lifting trays that weighed up to 50 pounds and inquiring further about the company’s pregnancy policies. Borders, who worked at an Illinois Wal-Mart, says she was reprimanded for asking coworkers to climb ladders and lift heavy boxes while she was pregnant, and forced to go on unpaid leave. When she returned, she says, she was paid $2.00 less per hour. The case is Borders v. Wal-Mart Stores Inc, U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois, No. 3:17-cv-00506. (Reporting by Daniel Wiessner in Albany, New York, Editing by Alexia Garamfalvi, Dan Grebler and Jonathan Oatis) Copyright 2017 Reuters. Click for restrictions. Wal-Mart Stores, pregnancy as disability, pregnancy discrimination, temporary disability accommodation, Walmart pregnant workers Have a hot lead? Send a tip! 208-528-NEWS Weather Sponsored By Local Idaho Falls Rexburg Pocatello Blackfoot Rigby St. Anthony Community Announcements Weather Sports US/World Idaho Utah Wyoming Montana National World Politics Live Better Comics/Puzzles East Idaho Newsmakers Feel Good Faith & Family East Idaho Eats Living the Wild Life Outdoors Health Money Local Business Lowest Gas Prices Business Cool Stuff Good Question Entertainment Technology Weird & Wacky Deseret Book building new store in Idaho Falls Local 0  Updated at 12:42 pm, May 16th, 2017 By: Paul Menser, BizMojo Idaho Share This Story We Matched IDAHO FALLS — A new bookstore is being built near Walmart in Idaho Falls. The building, at 750 Pioneer Road, will be the new home of Deseret Book, and it is going up in a hurry. The permit was applied for March 9 and issued April 11. Plans filed with the city of Idaho Falls show a total square-footage of 105,443 and a valuation (based on that square footage) of $404,365. Deseret Book has been located for years at 950 Memorial Drive near the newly-reopened Idaho Falls LDS Temple. There is also a store in the Ammon Town Center. The Deseret Book company dates back to 1919 and is a wholly owned subsidiary of Deseret Management Corp., the holding company for business firms owned by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. In addition to running a chain of stores in the western United States, Deseret Book publishes under four imprints with media ranging from works explaining LDS theology and doctrine, LDS-related fiction, electronic resources, and sound recordings such as Mormon Tabernacle Choir albums. A specific opening date for the store has not been announced. The story originally appeared on BizMojo Idaho. It is posted here with permission. NEVER MISS A STORY! Details Published: 2017-05-16 04:24:00 Updated: 2017-05-16 14:01:00 Comments Increase Text Size Print this story WRAL SmartShopper Swagbucks Swag Code until 3 pm for 3 SB! Tags: Freebies Posted 4:24 a.m. yesterday Updated 2:01 p.m. yesterday Leave this field blank Your e-mail address:* Your friends e-mail addresses (comma separated):* Subject:* Message:*A friend wanted you to see this item from WRAL.com: http://wr.al/185mQ Get a new codeAre you human?* You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters More on this Swagbucks.com website Stealth Swag Code Heads up! There is a Swagbucks Swag Code available today from 2 pm to 3 pm for 3 SB points! The code is: LetsGrill Enter the code in the Swag Code box at Swagbucks.com HERE. New to Swagbucks? If you don't know about Swagbucks yet, it's the largest rewards website that gives people free gift cards for the things they do online (searching, shopping, watching videos, playing games and more). You earn points called SB for online activities and then you can cash them in for gift cards to places like Amazon, Target, Walmart, CVS, Lowes, Starbucks, Paypal, Bass Pro Shops, Kohl's and so many more! It's free to join and I have earned a bunch of gift cards in the many years I have been a member. How do you get these SB points? There are lots of ways. * Search online: Each time you need to search for something online, use the Swagbucks search engine on their website (instead of Google). I actually have the Swagbucks toolbar installed on my desktop and it places a search box right on my screen making it super easy to search. Every once in a while, they award SB points just for doing the searches I used to do using Google. * Take surveys on their website * Answer the daily poll * Watch videos through their website or multiple mobile apps (I earn about 80 - 100 SB a day doing this) * Use their online shopping portal (I do most of my online shopping at major retailers who are part of the Swagbucks Shop and Earn program (like Amazon.com, Kohls.com, Walmart.com and more) and earn Swagbucks every time I shop. Just this week, I was credited with 562 SB points (worth $5.62 in gift cards) for an online purchase I made a few weeks ago. * Play games * Participate in special Swag Code events * Enter the daily Swag Code (which we usually let you know about here on the blog each day). Swagbucks posts bonus codes on their Facebook, Twitter and blog pages each day. If you have the Swagbucks Mobile App, it will buzz when there is a new code. When the code becomes available each day, one of us posts it here on the blog so we can all get it. The codes are only valid for an hour usually. Once you get the code, you then copy and paste the code into the Swag Code box at the top of the homepage of Swagbucks.com. Look for the circle with the words Swag Code next to it. New member bonus Swagbucks sign-up code! As I posted above, new members get a 70 SB bonus when you sign up HERE. To get the bonus SB points, click the text that reads "I have a sign up code" during registration and then enter the code: SMARTSHOPPER to get the bonus. Make sure you use all caps since it is case sensitive. This post contains affiliate links and I appreciate your using them! Credits Web Editor Faye Prosser Copyright 2017 by Capitol Broadcasting Company. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. Skip to content MilTech PR Distribution Menu HOME Add the press release Our team & Contact Posted on 16 May 2017 by Maciej Heyman EPD on the Beat – May 2017 On May 15, EPD responded to 271 calls for service and made 18 arrests. The average number of calls for service over the last seven days is 275 and the average number of arrests over the last seven days is 24. The number of calls for service on this day last year was 226, and the number of arrests was 30. Over the last three years, the average number of calls for service received on May 15 is 226, and the average number of arrests, 34.    05/15/17 15:45, 90100 BLOCK OF PRAIRIE RD False Information To Police/Warrant – Case 1707750 A police officer on patrol observed a male subject who was walking south on Prairie Road in the northbound bicycle lane, and also observed an available sidewalk on the west side of the roadway. The officer contacted the subject, who provided false identifying information to police, and was eventually identified as Andrew Curtis Benson, age 25, of Eugene, and that he had six warrants for arrest. Benson was arrested and transported to the Lane County Jail on the warrants and for False Information to Police. Benson was again contacted by police at the Lane County Jail and received eight additional charges for Fraudulent Use Credit Card (Cases 17-07285 and 17-06438). 05/15/17 12:30, BELTLINE EB/RIVER RD DUII/Reckless Driving/Hit and Run – Case 1707738 Police responded to the area regarding a hit and run and received information that an SUV entered the highway from the onramp in the number two lane and continued to travel into the number one lane and sideswiped a 2000 Honda Accord. The SUV continued to travel eastbound on Beltline after the Accord pulled off the roadway. Police located the described Ford Explorer SUV in the area near the bike bridge at Valley River Center and contacted the driver, Andrew Ryan Holman, age 26, of Eugene, and observed damage to the Explorer that appeared consistent with the information of the incident. After further investigation, police arrested Holman for Driving Under the Influence of Intoxicants, Hit and Run and Reckless Driving. He was also issued a citation for Driving While Suspended.   05/15/17 04:49, W 7TH AVE/CHAMBERS ST Disorderly Conduct – Case 1707702 Police responded to multiple calls regarding a male subject who was walking in traffic, and contacted the described subject, Erik Robert Farr, age 32, of Eugene. Following contact with Farr, he was arrested and transported to the Lane County Jail for Disorderly Conduct.   05/15/17 00:56, 2300 BLOCK OF ROOSEVELT BLVD Harassment/Warrant – Case 1707699 Police responded to an apartment at the location regarding a dispute between two male subjects who were staying at the residence. Police received information that the two subjects were in a verbal dispute that escalated when Sean William Brenton, age 32, pushed the 51-year-old male victim, who fell and hit his head. Following contact with Brenton, police found information to arrest him on a warrant. He was transported to the Lane County Jail on the warrant and cited for Harassment.   On May 10, EPD responded to 274, calls for service and made 21 arrests. The average number of calls for service over the last seven days is 296 and the average number of arrests over the last seven days is 25. The number of calls for service on this day last year was 257, and the number of arrests was 22. Over the last three years, the average number of calls for service received on May 10 is 225, and the average number of arrests, 26.  05/11/17 02:43, 399 JEFFERSON ST/W 4TH AVE Carry Concealed Weapon, Possession of Methamphetamine – Case 1707449 An officer patrolling observed a woman, later identified as Jaimie Alexandra Howell, age 20, in the Washington Jefferson Park after hours. He contacted her and found that she had a warrant. He arrested her on the warrant and found that she was in possession of methamphetamine and a concealed double-edged knife. She was charged with Possession of Methamphetamine and Carry Concealed Weapon. She was warned for violation of park rules. 05/11/17 00:01, 4098 W 11TH AVE/S BERTELSEN RD Warrant – Case 1707444 An officer was driving in the area and noticed an Acura Integra with very dark tinted side windows. He performed a traffic stop and contacted the driver, Matthew Anthony Ray Whipps-Hicks, age 27, of Eugene. He found that Whipps-Hicks’ driver’s license was suspended and that Whipps-Hicks had three warrants for arrest (Lane County Circuit Court Failure to Appear on charges of Hit and Run and Reckless Endangering, and Municipal Court Failure to Appear Resisting Arrest, and a parole violation for Rape 3). Whipps-Hicks’ license was suspended Driving While Suspended violation for Failure to Appear at a hearing. He was taken into custody on the warrants and issued a citation for Driving While Suspended and Driving Uninsured. 05/10/17 17:48, 3510 W 11TH AVE Interfering with Police Officer, Animal Abuse – Case 1707432 An officer was sent to help an animal welfare officer locate the owner of a male British Bulldog, Cletus, who had recently bitten two people and needed to be quarantined. They located the owner, Benjamin Scott Goodman, age 39, across the street from his vehicle. He walked over with his two dogs, including Cletus. He was advised of the need for quarantine for Cletus and he became upset. He indicated he would rather kill Cletus and appeared to start to choke the dog. An officer intervened with a warning and advised Goodman he would be tased if he did not comply. Goodman slammed Cletus on the ground and officers commanded Goodman to get on the ground. After initially not complying Goodwill got on the ground. Goodman was cited for Animal Abuse 2, and Cletus was impounded. The other dog was taken into Animal Welfare as Goodman was going to jail and no one could care for her. 03/06/17 09:00, Eugene Area Fraudulent Use Credit Card, ID Theft, Fail to Register as Sex Offender – Case 1705688 A 40-year-old man had applied for a credit card, but not received it. He was contacted by the credit card company as he had an overdue payment on the card that he hadn’t received. After an investigation, his former roommate, Christopher S Fish, age 40, of Eugene, was found to have taken the card and used it. Fish also had not registered his address and is a sex offender, and he was wanted on a Parole Violation for a previous conviction of Identity Theft. He was arrested on the warrant and also charged with Fraudulent Use Credit Card, ID Theft, and Failure to Register as a Sex Offender. 05/10/17 11:44, E 29TH AVE/WILLAMETTE ST Disorderly Subject – Case 1707398 Police responded to the area regarding a female who was yelling, screaming and kicking a vehicle. Police located the described subject, Rosemary Vesta Gray, age 39, of Eugene, and contacted her regarding the information. She was arrested and transported to the Lane County Jail for Disorderly Conduct.   05/10/17 09:31, 300 BLOCK OF N ADAMS ST Felon In Possession of Firearm/Possession of Methamphetamine/Criminal Trespass 2 – Case 1707392 A police officer patrolling the south bank bike trail in Maurie Jacobs Park was flagged down regarding camping and contacted Jesus Anthony Marinez, age 27, of Eugene, who was in the area. During contact with Marinez, the police officer found that he was in possession of a firearm and illegal drugs. He was arrested and transported to the Lane County Jail for Felon In Possession of a Firearm, Carry Concealed Weapon, Possession of Methamphetamine and Criminal Trespass in the Second Degree. On May 9, EPD responded to 299, calls for service and made 18 arrests. The average number of calls for service over the last seven days is 294 and the average number of arrests over the last seven days is 26. The number of calls for service on this day last year was 246, and the number of arrests was 21. Over the last three years, the average number of calls for service received on May 9 is 239, and the average number of arrests, 38. 05/10/17 02:40, 3100 CROCKER RD Possession of Heroin, Possession of Methamphetamine – Case 1707373 An officer spotted a Ford Escape with an obstructed rear window and noted the drive did not signal 100 feet prior to stopping along a curb. He contacted the driver, Wade Allen Arndt, age 49, of Eugene. Arndt did not have a driver’s license and there was a machete sticking up between the seat and center console. The officer asked him to get out of the car due to this and Arndt was compliant. The officer saw drug paraphernalia in the car. Arndt was suspended by Oregon DMV for Failure to Appear and he was also found to be in possession of heroin and meth. Arndt was charged with Possession of Methamphetamine and Possession of Heroin. 05/10/17 00:49, 4055 WAGNER ST Carry Concealed Weapon, Tampering with Physical Evidence, Possession of Methamphetamine, False Info to Police Officer – Case 1707371 An officer responded to the area of N. Clarey and Aerial Way regarding possible drug activity near a parked Ford Explorer. He contacted three individuals, including Nicholas Daniel Smith, age 19, of Eugene. Smith initially provided a false name and was in possession of brass knuckles. He was taken into custody and it was found he had a warrant out of Benton County for Possession of Controlled Substance Methamphetamine. He was found to be in Possession of Methamphetamine. Smith was charged with Carry Concealed Weapon, Tampering with Physical Evidence, Possession of Methamphetamine, and Providing False Info to Police Officer. 05/09/17 21:27, 590 E BROADWAY DUII, Driving While Suspended, Open Container – Case 1707366 An officer was dispatched after a man was reported to be intoxicated after driving to the 7-Eleven at 590 E. Broadway. The officer arrived and observed the man, later identified as Aceves-Arenzas Raul Garbriel Aceves-Arenzas, age 44, of Harrisburg, leaving in his car, then parking it on W. 2nd Avenue and Lawrence. The officer performed a stop and contacted the driver. After an investigation, an open container was found in the vehicle and it was found that Aceves-Arenzas was driving while suspended. He was charged with DUII, Driving While Suspended, and Open Container. 05/08/17 17:30, 1675 W 18TH AVE UUV, Forgery 1, ID Theft, Possession of Methamphetamine, Warrant – Case 1707359 A 1995 BVW sedan was stolen from a car dealership on May 8 after the female who entered the vehicle showed ID that was not hers, along with a check. She test drove it, but did not return. The check returned as not being valid. The car was spotted by the owner of the dealership and then it was parked at Albertson’s on W. 18th. There were four occupants and three entered the store, while one left the area. Officer arrived quickly and got a good description of the driver. Officers contacted the driver, Lindsay Kay Watson, age 34, inside the store. After an investigation it was found she had warrants out of Albany. she was charged with Unauthorized Use of a Vehicle, Forgery I, Identity Theft, and UPCS Methamphetamine. 03/12/17 19:07, 60 DIVISION AVE The suspect in the above case, was also a suspect in this one – Case 1706911 A woman, later identified as Lindsay Kay Watson, age 34, was found to have left the store with more than $1,000 of merchandise. She walked away from security who tried to stop her, and left in a vehicle. Video surveillance and a Lane County Mug Shots photo helped lead to identifying Watson. When she was arrested in case 1707359, above, she was also charged with Theft 1, for the shoplift. 05/09/17 20:09, 1165 WILLAMETTE ST Reckless Endangering – Case 1707364 A man and woman were having a verbal dispute and an officer was sent to the location. When he arrived, he found the man standing on the sidewalk looking above him and yelling. The officer found that while the two were fighting, a third party in a second-story apartment, identified as Donald Arthur Rich, age 41, of Eugene, had thrown large objects out of his window at the pair. The woman was able to get out of the way, but the man needed help as he had to get out of his wheel chair. After an investigation Rich was charged with Reckless Endangering. 05/09/17 07:00, 4550 W 11TH AVE Theft 1 – Case 1707322 An officer was sent to report of a trespasser in the 1200 block of Interior Street. When the officer arrived, the trespasser had left but the officer was provided a report that the subject had a cart full of possible stolen items that were still at the location, and a description of the suspect. This was close to Walmart and the shopping cart was from Walmart. The officer contacted Walmart and she got further details of a theft that had occurred earlier in the morning. She was able to identify the suspect as Natasha Ariane Hargrove, age 37, and that more than $1,000 in merchandise had been taken. Another officer stopped Hargrove at 1200 Bertelsen Road and the first officer took her into custody. 05/09/17 11:08, 2455 WILLAKENZIE RD Possession of Heroin, Criminal Trespass 2, Warrant – Case 1707328 An EPD School Resource officer at Sheldon High School received reports of a man, later identified as Anthony Jason Madonna, age 36, of Springfield, camping inside a tent near the high school softball field, which was on school property. Upon arrival, the officer contacted Madonna and found Madonna had two felony warrants. During the contact, the officer also found that Madonna was in possession of heroin. The officer took him into custody on the warrants and also charged him with Possession of Heroin and Criminal Trespass 2. 05/09/17 03:54, 300 BLOCK OF SUNSET DR Burglary 1, Unlawful Entry Motor Vehicle, Warrant – Case 1707312 In the early morning hours, a couple heard a noise in their garage and went to investigate. The male victim encountered a man, later identified as Zachary Michael Lobue, age 33, at the front of his garage and chased him north on Sunset Drive. The suspect dropped a cell phone during the chase. The victim stopped running and called 911. It was discovered that items had been taken from the garage, which they had forgotten to secure. The responding officers got a good description of the suspect. A community member called to report seeing the suspect at Franklin and Onyx. Based on that tip, EPD officers located Lobue at 11th and Franklin. Lobue had a warrant and he was taken into custody on that and also charged with Burglary 1 and Unlawful Entry Motor Vehicle. 05/09/17 05:47, 3700 CENTURY DR APT: BLK Possession of Methamphetamine, Warrant – Case 1707255 An officer on patrol saw a man on a bike without a rear reflector or red light. He stopped the man, identified as Derrick Joseph Bloomstrom, age 35. During the contact, the officer found Bloomstrom had four warrants for his arrest and was in possession of methamphetamine. His backpacks contained credit cards, gift cards, checks and mail for 17 different people. Attempts to locate victims of theft were not successful. Bloomstrom was taken into custody on the warrants and charged with Possession of Methamphetamine. On May 8, EPD responded to 314 calls for service and made 20 arrests. The average number of calls for service over the last seven days is 286 and the average number of arrests over the last seven days is 26. The number of calls for service on this day last year was 232, and the number of arrests was 37. Over the last three years, the average number of calls for service received on May 8 is 235, and the average number of arrests, 32.    05/08/17 23:27, 940 WILLAMETTE ST Harassment/Resisting Arrest – Case 1707304 Police responded to the area regarding two teenage females who were harassed by a group of juvenile subjects. Arriving officers observed the described subjects in the area of W. 10th Avenue, just east of Olive Street, and contacted a 16-year-old female juvenile who was charged with two counts of Physical Harassment and Resisting Arrest. During the arrest, the group of subjects surrounding the officers became hostile and a bystander intervened. Police transported the juvenile subject to SERBU and returned to the location after receiving information that the 52-year-old bystander had been assaulted (Case 1707303). The victim was transported to the hospital with serious injuries. 05/08/17 17:44, 100 BLOCK OF IOWA ST Felon In Possession of Restricted Weapon/Possession of Heroin/Warrant – Case 1707300 Police responded to a vacant lot regarding suspicious conditions and contacted a male subject who was in the area. During contact with the subject, David Michael Payne, age 57, of Eugene, police found that he had two warrants for arrest and was in possession of illegal drugs and a firearm. He was transported to the Lane County Jail on the warrants and for Possession of Heroin, Possession of Methamphetamine and Felon In Possession of a Firearm.    05/08/17 14:54, N WASHINGTON ST/CHESHIRE AVE Failure to Register Sex Offender/Warrant – Case 1707289 Police responded to Sinner’s Butte Park near N. Washington Street regarding a dispute and contacted Brian Matthew Lott, age 43, of Eugene. During contact with Lott, police found information to arrest him for Failure to Register Sex Offender and a warrant. He was transported to the Lane County Jail. 05/08/17 07:28, 1400 BLOCK OF OAK PATCH RD Criminal Trespass 1/Possession of Methamphetamine – Case 1707266 Police responded to a residence at the location regarding multiple trespassers who were observed on the premises of an unoccupied residence. Police located the two subjects at the residence, Jason Michael Furgason, age 42, of Eugene, and Michaela Christine Pond, age 27, of Eugene. Police contacted both subjects and cited Furgason in lieu of custody for Criminal Trespass in the First Degree. Pond was arrested and transported to the Lane County Jail for Possession of Methamphetamine and Criminal Trespass in the First Degree. On May 4, EPD responded to 297 calls for service and made 21 arrests. The average number of calls for service over the last seven days is 269 and the average number of arrests over the last seven days is 30. The number of calls for service on this day last year was 255, and the number of arrests was 26. Over the last three years, the average number of calls for service received on May 4 is 220, and the average number of arrests, 25.  05/05/17 00:55, HARLOW RD/FENSTER ST DUII/Reckless Driving – Case 1707067 Police responded to the area regarding a motorcycle crash and the arriving officer observed the blue 1996 Yamaha XV7 on its side in the middle of the road on Fenster Street. Police contacted the driver of the vehicle, Jonathan Cannoy, age 34, of Eugene, and after further investigation, found information to arrest him for DUII and Reckless Driving. 05/04/17 17:43, 2900 BLOCK OF STARK ST Interfering With Police Officer/Criminal Trespass 2/Warrant – Case 1707052 A police officer patrolling the area attempted to contact a female subject, Chloe Elizabeth Cantwell, age 25, of Eugene, who was recognized to have a warrant for arrest. When the officer exited the vehicle, Cantwell subsequently ran and continued to run after being given direction to stop. Police eventually located Cantwell, who was on the property of a residence without permission on the 2900 block of Crocker Road. She was arrested and transported to the Lane County Jail for Criminal Trespass in the Second Degree, Interfering With Police Officer and a warrant. 05/04/17 09:35, 4TH AVE/CHAMBERS ST DUII – Case 1707003 A police officer contacted the driver of a silver 2000 Mercedes Benz, Fidel Toribio Contreras-Sanchez, age 33, of Half Moon Bay California, after the vehicle was observed traveling south through a red light at the intersection of W. 2nd Avenue and Chambers Street. After further investigation, Contreras-Sanchez was arrested for DUII and cited for Failure To Obey Traffic Control Device. 05/04/17 02:59, W 7TH AVE/WILLAMETTE ALY Reckless Endangering/DUII – Case 1706991 A police officer patrolling the area observed a green 2001 Volvo weaving within its lane and changing lanes without signaling. The officer conducted a traffic stop of the vehicle and contacted the driver, Denice Francine Delbozque, age 24, of Eugene. After further investigation, she was arrested for DUII and Reckless Endangering. She was also cited for Driving While Suspended, Unsignaled Lane Change, and Driving Uninsured. 05/03/17 21:57, OLIVE ST/W BROADWAY Disorderly Conduct – Case 1706985 A police officer responded to a dispute at the location and received information of a male subject who had been approaching people in the area, yelling and behaving aggressively. Police contacted the subject, James Walter Everett, age 46, of Eugene, and were able to get him to leave the area. Minutes later, police were flagged down regarding Everett’s behavior and received information that he was approaching people and trying to get them to fight him. Police again contacted Everett and he continued to behave in a hostile manner with the officers. He was arrested and transported to the Lane County Jail for Disorderly Conduct.   On May 3, EPD responded to 293 calls for service and made 15 arrests. The average number of calls for service over the last seven days is 263 and the average number of arrests over the last seven days is 33. The number of calls for service on this day last year was 260, and the number of arrests was 16. Over the last three years, the average number of calls for service received on May 3 is 223, and the average number of arrests, 31.  05/03/17 07:42, 300 GOODPASTURE ISLAND RD APT Illegal Burning – Case 1706952 An officer was sent to the bike bridge just east of Goodpasture Island Road after a complaint about an illegal fire. The officer got there and followed the smoke to a camp with an open fire. He contacted two men, and one of them, Donam Lehi Gunter, age 42, was cited for Prohibited Outdoor Burning.  05/03/17 02:56, 3548 WILLOWBROOK ST/SANBORN AVE Unauthorized Use of Vehicle, Interfere with Police Officer – Case 1706948 An officer spotted a vehicle with a driver, later identified as Jacob Linus Evans, age 24. The officer noted the vehicle matched a stolen vehicle on his list. He followed it, but the car turned at Willowbrook Street and he found the car parked at a residence with no one inside. However, he did hear a noise coming from the backyard of the home. Officers and K-9 responded to search the area and K-9 Cjuk located Evans hiding in the backyard. The K9 officer called out for Evans to come out as the K-9 would be sent in if he didn’t. After there was no response, K9 Cjuk and his handler successfully took Evans into custody. He was charged with Unauthorized Use of Vehicle and Interfering with Police.  05/03/17 13:20, 200 BLOCK OF E 13TH AVE Criminal Trespass 1 – Case 1706962 Police responded to the location regarding a disorderly subject who had jumped multiple fences near the Circle K and was observed in the middle of the roadway yelling at cars. When police arrived, officers observed the subject, Casey Christian Westell, age 25, climb an apartment building and enter a residence on the second floor of the location. Police contacted him inside the residence and arrested him for Criminal Trespass in the First Degree.  05/02/17 21:51, 595 HWY 99N Possession of Methamphetamine – Case 1706942 An officer saw a Honda Civic jump the curb from Patty’s parking lot onto north bound Hwy. 99N. He stopped the vehicle and contacted the driver, Rina Yesenia Zaragoza, age 36, of Eugene, and found she was suspended for Delivery of Methamphetamine and currently on probation. After an investigation, she was found to be in possession of meth. She was charged with Possession of Methamphetamine. The officer also contacted the passenger, Daniel Alvarado Navarrete, age 24, of Eugene, and found that he had three warrants and was in possession of meth. He was charged with Possession of Methamphetamine and taken into custody on the warrants.  05/03/17 01:41, 1960 FRANKLIN BLVD Disorderly Conduct, Warrant – Case 1706947 An officer was sent to help CAHOOTS with a subject. When get got there, he found CAHOOTS was trying to get an intoxicated man to the hospital. The man, later identified as Steven Scott Sims, age 34, was walking in and out of traffic. He was also reported to have been hiding in the bushes and jumping out in front of women when they walked by, and trying to provoke a fight with security in the area. The officer contacted Sims at the 7-Eleven at 13th and Alder. Sims had a warrant for Theft 3 out of Sweethome. He was taken into custody and also charged with Disorderly Conduct. On May 2, EPD responded to 283 calls for service and made 23 arrests. The average number of calls for service over the last seven days is 255 and the average number of arrests over the last seven days is 33. The number of calls for service on this day last year was 264, and the number of arrests was 16. Over the last three years, the average number of calls for service received on May 2 is 261, and the average number of arrests, 31.  05/03/17 01:41, 1900 BLOCK OF FRANKLIN BLVD Disorderly Conduct/Warrant – Case 1706947 Police responded to the area of 13th Avenue and Alder regarding a male subject who was observed walking in and out of traffic and jumping out at people as they walked by. Police contacted the subject, Steven Scott Sims, age 34, of Eugene, and arrested him for Disorderly Conduct and a warrant. He was transported to the Lane County Jail.  05/02/17 21:52, 2600 BLOCK OF ROOSEVELT BLVD Criminal Trespass 1 – Case 1706944 Police responded to the area regarding a trespasser who was contacted by Portland Western Railroad and refused to leave the property. Police contacted the subject, Ronald Twiles Guptill, age 55, who was in the area of the railroad tracks and cited him in lieu of custody for Criminal Trespass in the First Degree. 05/02/17 19:35, 1080 WILLAMETTE STREET Assault/Disorderly Conduct/Interfering With Police – Case 1706937 Police responded to the area regarding a male subject who was observed assaulting another male subject at the location. The officer contacted the subject, Marquel Duan Cary, age 19, of Eugene, and he refused to follow direction and ran east through West Broadway Alley toward Willamette Street. Officers eventually contacted the subject in the 900 block area of Willamette Street and arrested him for Disorderly Conduct, Assault and a Interfering With Police. He was transported to the Lane County Jail. The 17-year-old victim was evaluated for minor injuries at the scene.  05/02/17 10:22, 2580 HILYARD ST Violation Park Rules – Case 1706901 An RV owner was reported parked at the Amazon Pool lot for several days and was reported to be cultivating marijuana in public view. An officer was dispatched to the location. He contacted the RV’s owner, William Watson Canfield, age 72. There was a marijuana plant in a pot on the RV’s hood. Canfield was cited for Violation of Park Rules and issued a 30-day park restriction. On May1, EPD responded to 257 calls for service and made 17 arrests. The average number of calls for service over the last seven days is 259 and the average number of arrests over the last seven days is 36. The number of calls for service on this day last year was 272, and the number of arrests was 34. Over the last three years, the average number of calls for service received on May 1 is 252, and the average number of arrests, 40.  05/01/17 03:10, 1060 JEFFERSON ST DUII Crash – Case 1706825 A single vehicle crashed and was on its roof at the location. Medics checked both occupants, who were not injured. An officer was dispatched as well and when he got there, he suspected impairment on the part of the driver,  Kylie Nicole Treadwell, age 23, of Eugene. During the investigation, it was found that Treadwell had hit a parked vehicle on the west side of Jefferson Street, before crashing onto its top. Treadwill was charged with DUII. 05/01/17 05:37, 2 CLUB RD/DAY ISLAND RD DUII – Case 1706821 An officer saw a Lexus in front of him going around a curve north onto Ferry Street Bridge then it crossed the divided line and sped onto the bridge. The officer stopped the vehicle and upon contacting the driver, Arvin Sanchez, age 28, of Eugene, he suspected impairment. After an investigation Sanchez was charged with DUII, and Failure to Drive in a Single Lane. 04/30/17 22:04, 100 W 8TH AVE/OLIVE ST DUII – Case 1706818 An officer spotted a Kia Spectra approaching a stop sign and it slowed, then turned and ran up and over the curb. The driver failed to use a turn signal when turning. It drove into W. 8th Alley, behind the Horsehead Tavern. The officer stopped the vehicle and contacted the driver, Stacey Ray Aldrich, age 42, of Eugene. Aldrich appeared impaired and after an investigation Aldrich was charged with DUII, Driving Uninsured, Failure to Obey Traffic Control Device, Improper Right Turn, Un-signaled Left Turn, and Open Container in Vehicle. 05/01/17 15:10, 4735 JESSEN DR APT Possession of Methamphetamine, Warrants – Case 1706864 An officer was sent to Golden Gardens Park to help an animal welfare officer with two wanted subjects. The officer identified the two as Stephanie Heather Grabb, age 38, of Eugene; and Mark Kevin Brown, age 50. During arrest, it was found Grabb was in possession of methamphetamine. Both were taken into custody on their warrants and Grabb was also charged with Possession of Methamphetamine. Watts leads Mathews Softball to District Title May 16, 2017 The Mustangs advance to face the winner of St. Thomas Aquinas/East Canton in the Division IV Regional Semifinals on May 24th at Kent State U… Gibson supplies 3 doubles to Canfield’s District Semifinal win May 16, 2017 Wolf & Columbiana baseball reached 20-wins in 2017 May 16, 2017 Cavalier paced Ursuline’s offense during the season May 16, 2017 Report It Community Community Events Community Resources Caring For Our Community Community Calendar Heroin Crisis Mental Health More About Us Advertise With Us Contact Us Contests Jobs News Team Watch CBS Shows Watch FOX Shows WKBN/FOX TV Schedule Obituaries Search for: Search the site 69° F Few Clouds Hi: 83° F Lo: 63° F Men accused of trying to steal TVs, hitting Liberty Walmart employee with buggy Police said Craig Honkonen and Aaron Jones were arrested down the street from the store By WKBN Staff Published: May 16, 2017, 1:54 pm Updated: May 16, 2017, 1:57 pm Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) Click to share on Google+ (Opens in new window) Share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) Craig Honkonen and Aaron Jones LIBERTY TWP., Ohio (WKBN) – Two men are facing charges after Walmart employees from the Liberty store accused them of trying to steal televisions and hitting an employee with a buggy in the process. The suspects were arrested a short time later down the street from the store, according to a police report. A caller reported the robbery just after 2 a.m. Saturday and reported that one of the suspects ran toward Belmont Avenue while another drove that way in a car. The televisions were left behind in the process. Police spotted a car matching the description of the suspect’s vehicle at the Shell gas station on Belmont Avenue. A man in the car, 35-year-old Craig Honkonen, was arrested. Police said he was covered in sweat and had clothing matching the description of the suspect’s in the vehicle. The other suspect, 47-year-old Aaron Jones, was spotted in the parking lot of Denny’s. Police said he had a pair of metal pliers in his pocket. Walmart employees confirmed that Honkonen and Jones were the men who tried to rob the store. They told police that they cut security devices from the televisions with the pliers and then tried to leave the store with the TVs. When stopped, they struggled with employees, and Honkonen hit an employee with the buggy, according to a police report. Police said during the investigation, it was found that Jones was asking people at Denny’s for money after the robbery. He told them that his car was broken down at the Shell gas station and he needed to get home to Columbus, according to a police report. Jones told police that Honkonen had come to Walmart to “do his thing” and said he was only there to get food, according to the report. Honkonen initially told police that Jones had threatened him with a gun and said he would kill him and his mother if he didn’t steal the televisions. When asked why he didn’t ask for help in the store, he told officers that he was scared but later admitted to being involved in the robbery, the report said. Honkonen is charged with robbery and complicity while Jones is charged with complicity, criminal damaging and possession of criminal tools. They are being held in Trumbull County Jail. . hrs ago Share Facebook Twitter Email Print This Story Written by Tom Steele, Breaking News Producer Connect with Tom Steele On Twitter Email Get Daily Dallas News Headlines Sign Up Don't miss a story. Like us on Facebook. Like Dallas News' Facebook Page Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now A woman says a man exposed himself to her outside a Grapevine Wal-Mart over the weekend. Police say the incident occurred around 6 p.m. Sunday at the Wal-Mart in the 1600 block of West State Highway 114, at Ira E. Woods Avenue, KTVT-TV (Channel 11) reports. The woman told police she was getting in her car to leave when a man got out of a gray Dodge Charger and approached her. He pulled down his pants and touched himself, the woman said. Police did not release a description of the man but said they were able to find his vehicle on surveillance footage of the parking lot. Business Business Opinion Opinion Tech Science Health Sports Sports Arts Arts Style Style Food Food Travel Magazine T Magazine Real Estate all Close search Site Search Navigation Search NYTimes.com Clear this text input Go Site Navigation Site Mobile Navigation Top News Trump Asked Comey to End Flynn Inquiry Ex-F.B.I. Director Documented Request in February Memo By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT In a meeting the day after Michael T. Flynn resigned as national security adviser, President Trump asked that the investigation into Mr. Flynn’s ties to Russia be shut down, according to a memo by James B. Comey. “I hope you can let this go,” the president told Mr. Comey. The White House has denied the account.  Comments 1:36 Exclusive: Trump, Comey and the Inquiry By A.J. CHAVAR Chaffetz Requests Trump-Comey Communications James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, during a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing this month. CNNMoney Investigates American Opportunity 5 Stunning Stats Growing India The Feed Markets Dollar takes a hit from Trump's latest crisis Investing Economy Buzz Fed Focus ETF Center Premarkets Market Movers Dow 30 After-Hours World Markets Before the Bell Romans’ Numeral Investing Guide Fear & Greed Quest Means Business Tech North Korea's long history of hacking Business Culture Gadgets Future Startups Powering Your World Upstarts Innovative Cities Unhackable 15 Questions Media Personal Finance Here's how to become a millionaire on $56,000 a year Save Spend Ahead Wheels Real Estate Careers Millennials & Money Your Money Homes Calculators Money Moves 24 Hours With Money Essentials My Watch List Loan Center Small Biz The factory where prisoners get a second chance Startups Empire Women Entrepreneurs Start Small, Think Big Luxury On the road - and on the track - in Ford's $450,000 supercar Style Away Rare Drive Wealth Rich Quiz The Collector A Gentleman's Guide Millionaire Calculator Log In Log Out Earnings This big retailer isn't getting Amazon-ed by Paul R. La Monica   @lamonicabuzz May 16, 2017: 10:55 AM ET Is the mall dead? It looks like most builders aren't buying plywood, concrete, bricks and other construction supplies from Amazon. Or even Walmart. They are doing so at Home Depot -- and that's why it is a bright spot in an otherwise gloomy time for traditional retailers. Home Depot reported earnings and revenues that topped Wall Street's forecasts Tuesday. The company also raised its profit outlook for the year. And it reported a same-store sales increase (stores open at least a year) of 5.5% overall and 6% in the US. Home Depot (HD) stock rose 2% in early trading to a new all-time high. The stock is now up nearly 20% this year, making it one of the top performers in the Dow this year -- along with Apple (AAPL, Tech30), McDonald's (MCD) and Visa (V). Home Depot is benefiting from a strong housing market. So is its rival Lowe's (LOW), which will report its latest results on May 24. Shares of Lowe's are up 20% this year as well. During a conference call with analysts Tuesday, Home Depot chief financial officer Carol Tomé said that the housing market continues to grow despite mixed forecasts for the overall economy. Housing prices have been steadily on the rise, which motivates prospective sellers to do home improvement projects to maximize the sale price for their house. Related: Retail train wreck continues as many big chains post declining sales Home Depot isn't ignoring the digital opportunities that have helped Amazon and Walmart either. Quite the contrary. Home Depot CEO Craig Menear said during the conference call that online sales rose 23% in the most recent quarter. But it clearly helps that both Home Depot and Lowe's are specialty stores that sell things that many people still want to buy at physical locations, especially professional builders and contractors. Menear added during the call that sales to its "Pro" customer segment continue to outpace that of average DIY customers looking to fix a broken closet door or leaky faucet. Still, Home Depot remains one of the exceptions in an otherwise dismal environment for many retailers. Related: Rue21 is the latest retailer to file for Chapter 11 Teen apparel retailer Rue21 announced Tuesday it was filing for bankruptcy protection, joining a long and growing list of retailers that have been forced to go the Chapter 11 route, such as Aeropostale, Wet Seal, Pacific Sunwear and The Sports Authority. Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF), once one of the hottest apparel chains for young adults, is looking to sell itself to a buyer as its sales continue to fall. Department stores Macy's (M), Sears (SHLD), JCPenney (JCP), Kohl's (KSS) and Nordstrom (JWN) have been struggling to compete with Amazon and Walmart as well. And two other retailers reported weak sales and gave sluggish outlooks on Tuesday -- T.J. Maxx and Marshalls owner TJX (TJX) and Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS). Shares of TJX fell 4% on the news while Dick's stock plunged 12%. That makes the gains for Home Depot on Tuesday all the more impressive. The company's signature color is orange. But perhaps Home should change that to green instead. It's one of the few traditional retailers not in the red lately, after all. CNNMoney (New York) First published May 16, 2017: 10:44 AM ET Social Surge - What's Trending Report: Trump told Comey to consider imprisoning reporters who publish leaks $1,000 in Amazon 20 years ago is now worth $638,000 Worldwide cyberattack: Here's how to protect yourself Mortgage & Savings Powered by LendingTree Terms & Conditions apply NMLS #1136 Newsletter Sponsored by Key market news. Menu Stocks Stocks to Buy Stocks to Sell Dividend Stocks Penny Stocks Hot Stocks Stock Market Today Funds Mutual Funds ETF Investing 401k & Investing Tips Retirement Financial Advisor Center Trading Trading Advice Trade of the Day Trading Report How to Trade Options Market Insight IPO Playbook Gadgets, Smartphones & Tech Weird Street InvestorPolitics Financial Advisors Premium Services Trading Advice Trade of the Day Trading Report How to Trade Options DOW- NASDAQ- S&P 500- Twitter (TWTR) hits new 2017 highs on Biz Stone return >>> READ MORE Breaking news sponsored by Home > Trading > Trading Advice > Trade Wal-Mart Stores Inc (WMT) Stock While It’s Down Earn a better yield on WMT stock than buying it at the sticker price By Nicolas Chahine, InvestorPlace Contributor  |  May 16, 2017, 10:14 am EDT     Popular Posts: Go Long Valeant Pharmaceuticals Intl Inc (VRX) Stock for Free Trade of the Day: Intel Corporation (INTC) Stock Is a Great Falling Knife to Catch Trade Walt Disney Co (DIS) Stock While Others Fear it Recent Posts: Trade Twilio Inc (TWLO) Stock for a Second Chance at the IPO Trade Wal-Mart Stores Inc (WMT) Stock While It’s Down No Lines for This Starbucks Corporation (SBUX) Stock Trade Refill View All Posts Wal-Mart Stores Inc (NYSE:WMT) is one of few retailers who is still doing well in the age of Amazon.com, Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN). Most other bricks-and-mortar stores are dying on the vine scrambling for market share. Source: Shutterstock Technically, WMT stock comes into earnings this week equidistant from its two-year highs and lows. I am a believer that markets overshoot on the way up and down. In Walmart’s case, this was clear to see on the chart — the price is in perfect balance relative to the extremes. Click to Enlarge Since the fundamental story for WMT stock is still as solid as ever, I am willing to take a risk on the long side even going into the uncertainty of earnings. I am a conservative trader, so I won’t risk $76 per share to buy WMT stock outright and with no room for error. Instead, I will use options to generate income from selling risk against support. The idea is not new, as I’ve demonstrated how easy it was back in March when I shared a trade that delivered profits with zero out-of-pocket expense. To me, Walmart’s strength is in its simple goal to be the low-price leader. I don’t hear as much about new efforts to improve its image, so management is focused on better execution of the plan at hand. The Trade: Sell WMT Dec $60 put and collect 50 cents per contract. With a 20% price buffer this trade has a 90% theoretical chance of maximum gains. If price falls below $59.50, I would accrue losses from having to own the stock. It is important to note that I am not chasing a price target since I just need WMT stock stay above my sold put to win. I am collecting a premium for the opportunity to own WMT stock at a 20% discount from the current price. In essence, I am selling someone a bearish WMT lotto ticket that will be a loser for them by design. Selling naked puts is not suited for all traders so to reduce the size of the risk I can change this setup to be a credit put spread instead, and it wouldn’t require a lot of compromise. The Alternate: Sell the WMT Dec $65/$60 credit put spread which has a slightly smaller price buffer but still could yield 8% on risk. Compare that with buying Walmart stock at $76 and needing it to rally 8% more to match the performance of the spread. Learn how to generate income from options here. Nicolas Chahine is the managing director of SellSpreads.com. As of this writing, he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at @racernic and stocktwits at @racernic.
